A implementação do programa de Novas Oportunidades levou à abertura de dezenas de centros de formação, que se acotovelam entre si na oferta de formação financiada. Esta situação criou expetativas irrealistas sobre o preço da formação. Hoje em dia as pessoas estão mais despertas para a necessidade de se qualificarem mas menos disponíveis para investir o seu próprio dinheiro nessa formação.
Na prática, isto obrigou as empresas do setor a reduzirem a sua oferta formativa ao Catálogo Nacional de Qualificações e dentro deste, a um pequeno leque de cursos para os quais conseguem formar turmas com facilidade.
As ações de formação que não se enquadram neste contexto, acabam por se desenvolver num mercado paralelo, onde os próprios formadores assumem a organização da ação por sua conta e risco. Neste caso há mais variedade, mas ainda assim, há muitos cursos que não passam do papel porque não se consegue reunir um grupo numa determinada zona ou horário.
Fora das grandes cidades, isto pode ser dramático. Ao contrário do que se julga, isto não afecta apenas o interior e as ilhas. Cidades litorais como as Caldas da Rainha e até capitais de distrito como Faro, sofrem do mesmo mal.
 
COMO É QUE O VAMOS FAZER?  

A REWINDD vai tornar o conhecimento acessível a todos. Estamos a desenvolver uma plataforma de formação de vídeo on demand, onde os formandos podem aceder aos cursos de 24 horas por dia, em qualquer lugar.
Queremos proporcionar uma experiência de formação bastante semelhante à sala de aula. Os cursos são desenhados especificamente para um ambiente online e usam técnicas específicas para assegurar que o aluno se sente como se tivesse o formador ao seu lado. Procuramos construir uma relações de empatia entre aluno e professor, apesar da distância.
Vamos lançar a plataforma com cursos nas áreas de finanças pessoais, design, web development, tecnologia, marketing, coaching, inteligência emocional, bem-estar e desenvolvimento pessoal, porque reconhecemos a necessidade para este temas no mercado. Ainda assim, pretendemos alargar a formação a outras áreas de conhecimento rapidamente e para isso contamos com a ajuda de nossos formandos que podem deixar sugestões no site.
Pretendemos levar a nossa plataforma de aprendizagem a todos os países de língua portuguesa como Angola, Brasil, Cabo Verde, Guiné, Moçambique, S. Tomé e Principe e Timor Leste e às comunidades portuguesas espalhadas por esse mundo fora.
Os utilizadores REWINDD vão beneficiar de ...


Autonomia, deixam de estar dependentes de terceiros.

Privacidade, podem fazer o curso no conforto da sua casa

Ritmo, podem aprender ao seu ritmo, ver e rever os vídeos quantas vezes quiserem.

Disponibilidade, os conteúdos estão disponíveis 24 horas por dia, 365 dias por semana.

Liberdade, para iniciar, interromper e retomar o curso quando quiserem, sem terem de se sujeitar a um cronograma pré-definido que numa versão presencial seria condicionado à disponibilidade do grupo, formador e sala de formação. 

Mobilidade, podem ver o curso em qualquer lugar.

Diversidade, formação em áreas relacionadas e complementares.

Nichos, conteúdos específicos que não encontram no mercado convencional porque a necessidade de reunir um grupo com interesse nesses temas e com disponibilidade para um mesmo horário e local, os inviabiliza.

Baixo preço, para a maioria, absolutamente grátis para aqueles que não podem pagar.

Acesso privilegiado ao formador para esclarecimento de dúvidas.

 
 
O QUE PODEMOS FAZER JUNTOS?
Juntos podemos dar a oportunidade a cada formando de fazer a formação que precisa independentemente da região onde vive, da sua disponibilidade em termos de horário e das suas condições financeiras. juntos, podemos fazer a diferença na vida de alguém!
 
 
O QUE FIZÉMOS ATÉ AGORA?
Lançámos há um ano atrás, uma experiência piloto e o feedback foi muito positivo. Os alunos que fizeram o curso webdesign que disponibilizámos disseram:
Eu gosto de fazer as coisas ao meu ritmo, e aqui tenho a chance para isso. 
Posso rever os vídeos quantas vezes quiser, voltar atrás, ver de novo de vez em quando e fazer o site no meu tempo.
 Há sempre aqueles detalhes que se perdem na sala de aula, porque estávamos focados na tarefa anterior, porque o telefone tocou ou porque estamos cansados. Neste modelo é fácil. Basta pausar, ir buscar uma sanduíche e voltar exatamente ao lugar onde estávamos com Sofia.
Desde então, desenvolvemos o conceito, desenhámos o logotipo, e começámos a desenvolver o site. Já estamos a reunir a equipa pedagógica e já temos alguém em mente para a produção dos vídeos. Precisamos agora de equipamento e software para aedição de vídeo e audio.
 
 
PARA O QUE VAI SER USADO O DINHEIRO?
O nosso objetivo é reunir fundos suficientes para financiar os primeiros 12 meses da REWINDD. Depois disso o projeto pagar-se-à a si próprio.
Temos como custos o desenvolvimento do site, a captura e edição dos videos de cada curso, bem como os custos de lançamento, expansão e divulgação para os próximos 12 meses. Agora precisamos de ajuda para terminar e lançar o projeto. Os recursos captados serão utilizados para finalizar o desenvolvimento do site, captura e edição de vídeo.


Os fundo recolhidos vão ser usados:

Bolsas de estudos, para alunos sem condições financeiras  
Desenvolvimento e alojamento do site
Equipamento e software de edição de audio e vídeo
Despesas de voluntários
Aluguer de espaço para as gravações
Comissões do Indiegogo

Se não conseguirmos a totalidade, o que for recolhido será usado:

No alojamento do site
Equipamento e software de edição de audio e vídeo
Comissões do Indiegogo




 
 
O QUE RECEBES EM TROCA?
Temos uns miminhos para quem nos ajudar:

Divulgação do TEU NOME / EMPRESA / MARCA como patrocinador oficial. Podes patrocininar um ebook, um curso, um autor, toda umacategoria ou o projeto na sua totalidade,
RECONHECIMENTO PÚBLICO na nossa página no facebook como apoiante do projeto,

DIGITAL PIN da REWINDD para poderes usar no teu perfil no Facebook ou Twitter,

CARTÃO DE AGRADECIMENTO especialmente desenhado para quem acarinhou o projeto.

 
 



OUTRAS FORMAS DE AJUDAR
Talvez não possas contribuir neste momento, mas isso não quer dizer que não possas ajudar:

Por favor, passa a palavra e faz um pouco de barulho sobre a nossa campanha. 
Partilha esta campanha no Facebook, Twitter, Google Plus, no teu blog ou manda por mail para os teus amigos. Deixa que os outros saibam que podem ajudar também.


 
 
Sobre a equipa
A equipa da REWINDD tem mais de 10 de experiência em formação presencial e mais de 15 anos de experiência em webdesign.

story:
Astronomy is Fun!

Astronomy and Cosmology have enlightened humanity since the dawn of time and will continue to do so into the future.  Our goal is to create an astronomical society in the South Jersey area that will serve to bring children and teachers an awareness of the universe we live in while creating fun, educational events in our community.  

The photo of the moon in our profile was taken with a camera phone held in front of the eyepiece of a simple 6 in. dobsonian-type telescope.  This demonstrates what almost anyone can do with relatively little effort if given the proper education and techniques.

Astronomy is Important!

Astronomy is the science that will bring our planet to the stars.  What we'd really like to contribute to our community is an enthusiasm - children are inundated with video games, cartoons, virtual reality, etc., but aside from the limited amount taught in elementary school, most kids have relatively little opportunity to explore and perform real science and to participate in such an engaging and rewarding hobby. Astronomy is one of the rare hobbies in which amateurs have the chance to make real scientific contribution.

Astronomy is Expensive!

While anyone with a pair of binoculars can be an 'amateur astronomer', it takes education, equipment and research to truly realize the benefits of engaging in astronomical work within a community.  Amateur astronomers have discovered asteroids, comets, deep-space objects and contributed to the scientific community in ways that other hard sciences simply do not allow for.  Astronomy club meetings and star parties are fun and fulfilling ways to bring together a community of hobbyists to do actual astronomical work, but resources are needed to being this effort and maintain it in an ongoing way.

The funding for the Society would go towards:

1) 16 in. Meade Telescope with built-in astronomical camera

3) 12 in. Meade Telescopes with built-in astronomical cameras

2) 6 - 10 in. dobsonian-type telescopes for students and beginners

8) Portable, carry-around Meade ETX-70 telescopes (to be loaned to students as part of an educational program in which students would be given a small, portable telescope to take home for the sake of observing astronomical objects, preparing data on the movement of those objects and giving in-class presentations to report their observations)

1) Van or truck with logo and storage for transporting telescopes and equipment to schools, star parties, astronomical events (eclipses, transits, etc.) 

Logo design, branding and stationary (this is an important piece of the puzzle as recruitment, initially, will be our primary effort)

Modifications to existing rented structure for storage and observing (fitted, ready-made dome/observatory)

Monthly dues will be somewhere in the neighborhood of $15 with a discount for yearly dues paid up front.  One policy that will distinguish MAS from other astronomy clubs is that membership for children under 18 will always be free.

One final note - I've been an amateur astronomer for over 20 years and simply put, it is what I'm most passionate about.  2-3 times a month, I show friends or family members a view of the moon, one or more of the planets, deep-space objects or nebula through my small, inexpensive telescope and without exception, they are all astounded by what they see.  Most people simply assume that astronomy as a hobby is too expensive or complicated or else they don't have the time to participate within their busy lives.  But when shown what's in the sky by someone who shares this passion, they fall under its spell and realize what beauty and majesty exists right above their heads.  I'd love to be able to educate people and bring this same awareness to as many people as possible.  If I could give one piece of advice to everyone I meet, regardless of what age, walk of life or career, it would be to simply 'look up'...you just don't know what's out there.

story:
Bonjour!

Je m'appelles Jean, je suis étudiant en Langues à l'université de Rennes 2. J'ai eu la chance de voyager au Kenya en 2010. Le but du séjour était de découvrir ce pays dont les richesses culturelles et naturelles attirent chaque année des centaines de miliers de touristes du monde entier. A mon arrivée, j'ai été hébergé chez Mr Oyugi, directeur d'une école assez particulière qu'il a fondé il ya plus de 10 ans, il a été un vrai père pour de nombreux orphelins du district de Homa Bay.



L'école


La "King Solomon Junior School" à un rôle social majeur à jouer dans la région car elle accueille des enfants issus de milieux défavorisés ainsi que des orphelins et leur offre l'opportunité d'accéder à une éducation de qualité. En effet, cette année l'école s'est classée deuxième du district à l'examen national, le KCPE (équivalent à notre Baccalaureat), sur plus de 300 écoles!


Afin de venir en aide aux familles les plus démunies et de permettre à leurs enfants de se construire un avenir décent, la politique de l'école concernant le règlement des frais de scolarité est souple. Il s'agit de trouver, avec les parents qui ne peuvent pas payer, des solutions pratiques comme faire participer ces parents à la vie de l'école. Certains viennent aider à couper du bois pour la cuisine, d'autres viennent effectuer des travaux de peinture ou de maçonnerie, pour les familles qui travaillent dans l'agriculture et la pêche il est également possible de payer en aliments.



La situation


Le taux de VIH et de paludisme étant très élevé dans la région, de nombreux enfants deviennent orphelins très jeunes. Mr Oyugi fait de son mieux pour les élever convenablement avec de faibles ressources, cependant la tâche est rendue plus difficiles quand les conditions sanitaires ne sont pas bonnes.


L'eau est un problème majeur


Au cours de la saison sèche, la population n'accède que très difficilement à l'eau potable et se tourne bien souvent vers le lac Victoria, tout proche, pour aller y puiser l'eau qui servira à leurs besoins journaliers. Cette eau n'est pas propre à la consommation, pourtant beaucoup de personnes n'ont d'autre choix que de la boire pour survivre.


Ainsi, nous avons décidé de construire un réservoir d'eau de pluie enterré, qui collectera l'eau durant la saison des pluies et pourra contenir suffisamment d'eau pour alimenter l'école tout au long de l'année.



En participant à la réalisation de notre projet, vous permettrez aux enfants de Homa Bay de rendre leur futur plus digne. La devise de l'école est "La Connaissance c'est la Vie". Je crois que c'est une vérité. Seule l'éducation pourra permettre aux plus démunis d'améliorer leur niveau de vie.


La saison des pluies commençant à peine, plus vite nous aurront réuni le budget nécessaire à la construction du réservoir, plus nous pourront collecter d'eau pour passer la saison sèche.

Ci-dessous le budget prévisionnel détaillé:



Si vous pensez que le jeu en vaut la chandelle, partagez notre projet autour de vous! Un grand merci à ceux qui permettront à ces enfants de se focaliser davantage sur leurs études que sur leur état de santé.



......................................................................................................................................


Hello!


My name is Jean, I'm a student, I live in France where I was born and raised.
I travelled to Kenya in 2010 because I wanted to discover this beautiful country.
I stayed for two months at Mr Oyugi's house who is a real father for many orphans of the district of Homa Bay. He has been running a very special school for more than 10 years.


About the school


"King Solomon Junior School" has an important social role to play in the province as it hosts children from humble backgrounds and gives them the possibility to access quality education. As a matter of fact, this year the school went second in terms of results at the national exam within the whole county, which counts more than 300 schools!

In order to help the most needy families offering their children a future, the school's policy is to figure out case by case ways of arrangement concerning the fees. Some parents who can't afford the bill come to help by achieving some tasks there such as cutting firewood, painting walls, etc... Others may give some food if they work in the fields or if they fish.


Here is the situation


As the rate of HIV and malaria contamination is very high, many children here become orphans very soon. Mr Oyugi tries his best to grow them safely. This task is made harder when sanitary conditions are bad.

 Water is a big problem there


During the dry season people cannot access clean drinkable water and many go to the Lake Victoria nearby to fetch water for drinking. This water is not good for consumption.



That is why we decided to help those children by building an underground water tank which will collect rainwater from the roofs of the school and enable the children to get clean water all through the year.




By helping us achieving our goal, you will ensure the children of Homa Bay means to make their future brighter. The motto of the school is: "Knowledge is Life". I believe this is true. Education only can make solutions for the needy ones to improve their living.



As the rainy season just starts, the faster we will manage to raise the amount needed, the better it will be as this would be an opportunity to start collecting clean water for the coming year.

Hereinbelow our estimated budget for the building:



If you think this is worth helping us, please share our project with your friends!
Thanks a lot to those who will allow these children to focus more on their studies than on their health.

story:
Hello! My name is Arielle Atkinson! I am 15 and a freshman and I am very active in my youth group, B'nai B'rith Youth Organization (BBYO). BBYO is the largest pluralistic Jewish youth movement in the world. This coming summer I am hoping to go on my first international event with BBYO. I am trying  to go to  Chapter Leadership Training Conference (CLTC) 2014. At CLTC, I will be spending time at Bethany college  in West Virginia learning leadership skills, meeting other B'nai B'rith Girls from across the country, and exploring my Jewish identity. My attending this program will benefit my chapter immensely, as i will run for  higher positions on my chapter and regional board and use the skills I will learn at CLTC to improve and better my chapter as a whole. I will prove not only my potential, but increase the potential of my chapter. 

BBYO not only helps young Jewish teens, but it also helps the community. My chapter and region  has raised thousands of dollars for several causes, such as Students Supporting Brain Tumor Research (SSBTR), and the Special Olympics. We have also spent hours volunteering places, such as Kivel Retirement Home, and the SSBTR walk-a-thon.

Last January, a bit under a year and a half ago, i joined my BBYO chapter, Joyce Eva Kiviat BBG #646 and immediately bonded with the amazing girls that make up this chapter. I've made best friends and sisters, something I would not want to miss out on if i was not apart of this amazing order. This program will further my BBYO career in ways that only this program can do.  I've heard so many great things about CLTC and I can not wait to experience it for myself.

A typical day at CLTC includes leadership classes, “how to” sessions, evening programs, chapter planning and supervised free time. I would be so appreciative of any donation you could make, whether it is money or wishing me safe travels. I plan on taking hundreds of photos and keeping a notebook at CLTC and I am so excited to share with others what I will learn. I look forward to speaking with you and I thank you for reading this!

Yours Truly,

Arielle Atkinson

story:
Morne Oge in Jacmel, Haiti

Since 2005 Restore Haiti has been working with impoverished communities to provide assistance in the areas of:
  • Healthcare
  • Education
  • Food
  • Basic living conditions 
We believe that education is a key to seeing change happen in Haiti, and making sure students have the supplies they need to start the school year off right helps contribute to their success. By helping Restore Haiti provide school supplies to children in Haiti, supporters are helping to set the tone for the school year, and sending a message to these students that education is critical and so important that someone cares enough to make sure they have the supplies they need.

We need $15,000 to provide supplies to 1,000 children

We purchase supplies in bulk in order to get the best pricing and volunteers assemble the packets each child will receive.  
Packs include (varies by grade level)
  • Backpacks
  • Pencils and erasers
  • Pencil sharpeners
  • Pens
  • Rulers
  • Compasses
  • Calculators
Restore Haiti has a team of volunteers already booked to distribute these packets in mid-August, and will be sending you a distribution recap including photos of the students receiving their supply packets.

The Impact

“Education is the single best investment in prosperous, healthy and equitable societies.” – UN Food & Agriculture Organization

  • No country has ever achieved rapid and continuous economic growth without at least a 40% literacy rate.
  • A single year of primary school increases a boy’s future earning potential by five to 15% and a girl’s even more.
  • A child born to a literate mother is 50% more likely to survive past the age of five.
  • Education and food security are directly connected: doubling primary school attendance among impoverished rural children can cut food insecurity by up to 25%.

Other Ways You Can Help

Get your office, church, small group on board to help with this project. Share on Facebook, twitter, and Instagram to get your friends involved. To sponsor a specific child monthly, which helps cover their food, education, and basic healthcare, visit us at www.restorehaiti.com

Healthcare
Education
Food

story:
What Is Electric Girls?

Electric Girls is a 12-week education program for girls ages 9-14 in New Orleans. Using a mentorship structure, we teach girls to become leaders and role models in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math). Girls come away with a new set of hard skills (soldering, drilling, building circuits, etc.) and soft skills (perseverance, curiosity, leadership, self-motivation).


Help the Electric Girls Community Grow

Our $10,000 goal will help fund the Electric Girls program this upcoming school year. The money will go towards:

  • Program Equipment: Everything we need to create a the best environment for our girls - soldering stations, batteries, tools, design journals, insurance, marketing and a space for us to work in.
  • Scholarships: Your contributions will allow us to supply scholarships for girls who are not able to pay the full program fee.


How Do We Get Girls to Stick to STEM?

We strive to develop girls into confident leaders in science and technology. We believe that to get girls to have a long-lasting interest in science and technology, we need to do a lot more than just expose them to STEM kits and tools - Electric Girls in not the next big STEM toy for girls - it is a community of girls and women teaching each other to be leaders in STEM. 

The Impact

In a series of studies in 2003, first through fourth grade girls tended to associate mathematicians as male more than female, and tended to say that males liked and were better at math than women.


Of the 20 projected fastest growing occupations in 2014, 15 of those require significant mathematics or science preparation (US Dept. of Labor Statistics).  Yet, women comprise only 24% of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics career holders even though they comprise 48% of all job holders in the country. 

Electric Girls is here to change the pace of STEM education for girls, and we're starting in New Orleans. We've tested, iterated, and improved our program with more than 100 girls in less than 6 months, and we're ready to launch this fall. 


Our Challenge

$10,000 is a lot of money. The good news is, it will go a long way. If we don't reach our goal, we'll still be able fund Electric Girls this fall - but with less room for equipment purchases and with less capacity for more Electric Girls. 

The Electric Girls team is so passionate about giving girls the highest quality STEM education, that we volunteer our time as unpaid employees, even though we work full-time. We've taken on this challenge for the last six months and we aren't about to stop now. 


THANK YOU!

We want to give a huge thanks to everyone who has supported us thus far and helped us shape the future for girls in technology. We couldn't have done it without our good friends at 4.0 Schools, the Delta Regional Authority, Loyola University, The New Orleans Mini Maker Faire, Antigravity Magazine, Maker Krewe, and more. 
But most of all, we want to thank the Electric Girls and their parents that we've had the honor of working with so far. You all inspire us every day! Thank You!

story:
Why I'm Doing This

As a young activist and trainer of color, I feel blessed to have gotten support from many wonderful mentors and colleagues in my journey to cultivate my skills and experience.  I know that few of us have that kind of support along the way and that's why, in my role as TFC Co-Director, I've designed a new fellowship program to offer more opportunities for trainers of color to get coaching, practice, and focused attention. 

This fellowship is my way of making sure that people of color are prioritized in how we build leadership within Training for Change and that we continue to provide resource that can help trainers of color further their goals and do their best work in their organizations and communities.

While others in Training for Change are supporting our fundraising in a variety of ways, I've made a personal commitment to raise $2,000 in order to launch the fellowship program at the end of this year.

The Judith C. Jones Fellowship Program

Starting in 2014, Training for Change will accept 2 Fellows for a year-long term in which they will receive:
 
- Ongoing one-on-one coaching with an experienced trainer to help them identify and work towards any goals they have for themselves as a trainer, facilitator, or organizer.
- Opportunities to co-facilitate with other TFC trainers.
- Support to develop workshop designs, tools, and techniques for a training or facilitation context that they're currently working in.
- Full scholarships to any TFC trainings they want to attend during their fellowship.
- A travel stipend of $500 to assist with cost of attending TFC trainings or workshops in other modalities that they'd like to attend.
 
The fellowship is named in honor of TFC trainer Judith Jones (pictured above) who has been an important source of eldership and wisdom for many of us in TFC and continues to be a good friend and mentor for me and my work as a trainer. 

Your Support

Your gift will help us reach our goal of launching the Judith C. Jones Fellowship this year.  All funds raised through this campaign will go toward travel stipend and scholarship funds for our fellows, and allow us to pay our trainers and staff for the hours they put in to supporting this program.

story:
Thank you to all who have contributed! Please continue to share with others! Thank you.

My rotary sponsor clubs will be paying the program fee. All I need now is  $3,000.  Please keep donating and help me reach my goal! Thank you 

MY STORY

สวัสดีค่ะ (S̄wạs̄dī kh̀a) / Hello,

My name is Marilee and I have been accepted to the Rotary Youth Exchange Program and will be spending a year in Thailand from 2014-2015. This is an amazing opportunity for me. I will be able to embrace the culture and language of the people of Thailand. Thailand is a Mystical Kingdom from its beautiful Buddhist temples to its exotic wildlife and unique cuisine. 

MI HISTORIA

สวัสดีค่ะ (S̄wạs̄dī kh̀a) / Hola, 

Mi nombre es Marilee y yo he sido aceptado en el programa de Intercambio de Jóvenes con Rotary y voy a pasar un año en Tailandia 2014-2015. Esta es una oportunidad increíble para mí. Voy a ser capaz de abrazar la cultura y la lengua de la gente de Tailandia. Tailandia es un reino místico de sus hermosos templos budistas para su fauna exótica y cocina única.

In this program I will spend a year in Thailand. Thailand is located in Southeast Asia.

 There I will live with 3 different host families where I will be able to get a better perspective of the culture through different points of views.

En este programa  voy a pasar un año en Tailandia. Tailandia se encuentra en el sudeste de Asia. Yo voy a vivir con 3 diferentes familias de acogida donde voy a ser capaz de obtener una mejor perspectiva de la cultura a través de diferentes puntos de vista.

WHAT I HOPE TO GAIN:
  • Learn the Thai language
  • Experience the culture
  • Develop a better understanding of the World
  • Gain new experiences
  • Become Independent
  • Become more Responsible
  • Learn to cook Thai cuisine
  • Learn to Swim
LO QUE ESPERO PARA GANAR:
  • Aprenda el idioma tailandés 
  • La experiencia de la cultura 
  • Desarrollar una mejor comprensión del mundo 
  • Adquirir nuevas experiencias 
  • independizarse 
  • Ser más responsable 
  • Aprende a cocinar cocina tailandesa 
  • Aprender a nadar

  I believe that this program will help me further my education. In college I hope to study Anthropology (Cultural or Linguistics), Asian Studies, and also learn even more languages and so this program will give me a head start in college.  I will be learning and bringing the knowledge to share with others when I come back.

Yo creo que este programa me ayudará a continuar con mi educación. En la universidad yo espero estudiar Antropología (Cultural o Lingüística), Estudios de Asia, y también aprender más idiomas y por lo que este programa me dará una ventaja inicial en la universidad. Estaré aprendiendo y llevando el conocimiento para compartir con los demás cuando vuelva.


FUNDS

In order for me to embark on this great opportunity, I must raise a total of $3,000 (This includes the additional funds I'll need) Please help me by donating to my campaign. Any contribution made will bring me closer to a once-in-a-life-time experience. 

FONDOS

Para que me embarco en esta gran oportunidad, tengo que recaudar un total de $3,000 (Esto incluye los fondos adicionales que necesitaré) Por favor, ayúdame con la donación de mi campaña. Cualquier contribución que me acercará más a una experiencia única en un curso de la vida.


DONATION

Thank you and if you can please spread the the word I'll really appreciate it. You could also use the Indiegogo Share Tools to share my campaign with others. 

DONATIÓN

Gracias y si puede por favor difundir la palabra, lo agradezco mucho. También es posible usar los IndieGoGo Share Herramientas difundir mi página a los demás.


For More Information on Rotary or the Rotary Youth Exchange Program visit the following links:

Rotary: https://www.rotary.org/

Rotary Youth Exchange: https://www.rotary.org/en/youth-exchanges

Para más información sobre Rotary o el Programa de Intercambio de Jóvenes, visite los siguientes enlaces:

Rotary: https://www.rotary.org/es

Intercambio De Jóvenes: http://yex7210.org/es/

story:
Hello, my name is Lia Mari Menard. I am the CEO and Co-Founder of Living Lake Global Community Center. I’ve volunteered to assist a dear friend with his mission.

Working with local officials, Zain Jaelani is building a school for his daughter, and the children of his village on Lombok Island in Indonesia. Zain has been working and saving for 3 years to build a preschool. Without our help, it will take him another 3 years to save the needed funds. I am utterly amazed what one man, alone, accomplish!

With Your help, the team on Lombok can have their funds in less than 90 days, in time to build in the spring. So little money can go so far with this project! We help them build the preschool, and they will have generations of children learning in an adequate and safe environment.

A better school will allow the parents, who are currently having to tuition their children out in neighboring towns, to keep their children close to home, a new local school will allow families more time together, fathers might not have to leave the home and island for work, and the children will have more time to play too of course!

Because of high the costs families must pay for tuition and travel, fathers are having to leave the village and often the island altogether looking for higher paying work, to earn enough money to educate their children, thus leaving families virtually fatherless. A vicious cycle this community is working diligently to break, they will continue to work, and they will succeed.

From these humble beginnings, Zain and the team intend to use what they have learned through this process to assist other people around the world to build needed schools in their communities.

What we need and what you get...

When I asked Zain how much money he needed, he said “$5,000”.
I was shocked… For us in the United States, it sounds like such a small goal for a group of people to reach.

I have doubled Zain's figure and with good reason. As we all know, things never go as planned, unexpected costs come up when building. If there are any surplus funds after building the preschool, these funds will be used to buy books, supplies, and possibly help offset the costs of the first year of teacher salaries, to help them get off to a great start.

I am very hopeful we will raise these 'extra' funds for the books and supplies. I know that the children will have a better start in their new school when they have the adequate tools.

If we do not receive enough funds to begin building, the money we do collect will be placed in bank accounts, wisely accruing interest, as we locate the remaining funds needed as quickly as possible.

What you get: Aside from instant sincere gratitude, all contributors to the preschool project can download a free copy of one of my eBooks. That is, a contribution as little as a $5= A wonderfully inspirational book! The more you give, the more we give too! For $25, you get my eBook, but also you can download Len Branson's documentary, "Superwise Me!".  For $100 You receive the eBook, Len's movie, and you will also receive a signed photo of the children in the new school once it's built. Contributions of $1000 or more, get all of the gifts, plus, a handmade card from the children.

The Impact

Many of the parents who have difficulty affording the tuition costs,  are praying for the new school. The spacious Loving Energy of the New School is sure to attract quality teachers, and thus, a better education for their children.

Zain is certain that the main cause of the economic pressures families face on Lombok is due, in large part, to the poor education received in early childhood. Of course, we know this is true. Lack of education is a leading factor in poverty and so many other social issues. I can empathize with Zain in his unwavering desire to do whatever it takes to give his daughter the education he was not able to get. We applaud his effort and dream.

Your generosity with our campaign can not be measured in terms of your impact on this community and the world. As there is no way to determine the numbers of apples in a seed, there is no way to measure the far reaching effect of a good early education for these children.

Your contributions will change our world for the better.
Of that there can be no doubt.

If you are unable to contribute financially, please, share our campaign widely throughout your social media and come follow us on Facebook.

story:
Hi there!

Thank you so much for visiting our fundraising page! We are 15 students attending Harvard University in Cambridge, MA and we are currently planning a service trip to the Philippines this January. Before our trip, we are amassing funds to help us carry out our chosen project.

The particular project we will be implementing in January is being planned in conjunction with Child Hope Asia, a non-profit organization which promotes education for Filipino street kids, most of whom live in cardboard boxes by the side of the road and are exposed to a variety of negative influences. Last year's team--the first group of undergraduates to ever do this service trip to the Philippines--held a series of self-expression workshops with the street kids, doing things from singing and dancing to art and photography. The project culminated in a giant showcase called "Ang Kwento Ko" ("My Story"), where the kids performed onstage and money was raised for the cause. The video above is a sneak preview into how the week went.

Mr. Timothy Boulton, superintendent at Aguinaldo International School who works closely with Child Hope. has expressed his desire to have us join them again for two weeks to strengthen the program and to possibly make this an annual trip. Stairway Foundation,a rehabilitation center for physically and sexually abused street children based in Mindoro, has invited us to visit them and interact with their kids as well.

Because of budget constraints, however, we’ve found that our ability to fund many of the costs associated with a trip to the Philippines is limited. On top of paying for airfare, we will also have to pay for food and internal travel expenses. As such, we are asking generous individuals such as yourself to consider donating to our cause.

If you wish to contact us, you may do so at hpfmentoring@gmail.com.  If you would like to learn more about last year's trip and what we achieved, please don’t hesitate to view the team's blog from last year: www.harvardphilippinejterm.wordpress.com or website at www.harvardphilippineforum.weebly.com/j-term-2014.html Thank you so much for all your help!

Sincerely,

The Harvard Philippine J-Term 2014 Team
story_txt:
Hi there!
Thank you so much for visiting our fundraising page! We are 15 students attending Harvard University in Cambridge, MA and we are currently planning a service trip to the Philippines this January. Before our trip, we are amassing funds to help us carry out our chosen project.
The particular project we will be implementing in January is being planned in conjunction with Child Hope Asia, a non-profit organization which promotes education for Filipino street kids, most of whom live in cardboard boxes by the side of the road and are exposed to a variety of negative influences. Last year's team--the first group of undergraduates to ever do this service trip to the Philippines--held a series of self-expression workshops with the street kids, doing things from singing and dancing to art and photography. The project culminated in a giant showcase called "Ang Kwento Ko" ("My Story"), where the kids performed onstage and money was raised for the cause. The video above is a sneak preview into how the week went.
Mr. Timothy Boulton, superintendent at Aguinaldo International School who works closely with Child Hope. has expressed his desire to have us join them again for two weeks to strengthen the program and to possibly make this an annual trip. Stairway Foundation,a rehabilitation center for physically and sexually abused street children based in Mindoro, has invited us to visit them and interact with their kids as well.
Because of budget constraints, however, we’ve found that our ability to fund many of the costs associated with a trip to the Philippines is limited. On top of paying for airfare, we will also have to pay for food and internal travel expenses. As such, we are asking generous individuals such as yourself to consider donating to our cause.
If you wish to contact us, you may do so at hpfmentoring@gmail.com.  If you would like to learn more about last year's trip and what we achieved, please don’t hesitate to view the team's blog from last year: www.harvardphilippinejterm.wordpress.com or website at www.harvardphilippineforum.weebly.com/j-term-2014.html Thank you so much for all your help!
Sincerely,
The Harvard Philippine J-Term 2014 Team

story:
Support our children. Give them posters for their bedroom walls that instill values of discipline, focus, innovation, perseverance and purpose. Turn our children away from images that celebrate conspicuous consumption, promiscuity and violence.
 
Each ten dollar contribution will print a 24" x 18" poster. Posters will be given to libraries, schools and civic organizations to be distributed to children throughout the United States.
 
For a one hundred dollars or more contribution, you will receive a mounted poster of your own.
 
Our children's lives are saturated with images that extoll violence, sex and idle play. These posters will show our children that there is another way to view the world; another way to re-define their purpose in life and aspire for greater goals.
 
Getting our children to re-define their purpose in life and aspire for greater goals will, ultimately, make for a better society for it is our children who will carry on after we leave this earth.

story:
Hi Everyone!

I have made this page for my good friend Sok. 

Sok is a Cambodian man with a heart of pure gold. 

Sok was a victim of the Cambodian Genocide and lost his entire family in the violent killings. From the age of 14 Sok lived on the streets and supported himself. After many years of struggling to support and feed himself he became a tour guide at Angkor Wot in Siem Reap.

Sok has worked as a tour guide for over 10 years now and has dedicated his life and earnings to supporting other children who have lost their parents or who go on day in day out without food or basic human rights.

Sok has run an orphanage for over 40 abandoned children for nearly 9 years now. He provides a shelter, education and food to children ages 2-15.

Not only has sok dedicated his life to these amazing children but he has gone even further and this year in July he opened the only free education provider in the village area he lives in. The school has been open only 2 months when i arrived to help teach and already had over 600 students.

Sok uses every donation for not only the children in his care but the surrounding village children who need just as much help as the children in the Orphanage.

Sok is a truly inspirational person. When i was there he was hospitalized with Denghy fever and was very very ill. Against all doctors orders he kept checking himself out to help the children.

The children themselves are such beautiful souls and take very opportunity to learn. Currently there are 27 girls in the orphanage who share 3 x double beds. Sok is raising funds to build a new larger home so he can take on more and more children who need help.

I hope to raise as much money as possible to help make Sok's goal a reality and to help the beautiful kids have a real shot at life!

If you cant donate or want to help in any other ways Sok is ALWAYS looking for people to come teach in the school or help with simple tasks like showering and feeding the younger children. I have no educational background in teaching and was welcomed  with open arms and allowed to teach the children each day. Please get into contact with me should you wish to visit Sok and the Kiddies.

story:
These are the students who should go to GHC

You've heard about the diversity problems in tech: incredibly low percentages of women and minorities in some of the best-paying jobs. By some estimates, only 1% of all tech workers are Latina.

In our computer science program, we're lucky to buck the trend. Within our cohort-based degree program, CSIT-In-3, we have 39% female students, 90% Latino students, and 85% first generation college students. We have so many female students that they couldn't all receive scholarships through the official GHC scholarship fund. That's where you come in!

  • I'm the Computer Science education coordinator for CSIT-In-3, an intensive, accelerated Computer Science Bachelor's degree program at Hartnell College and CSU Monterey Bay
  • Grace Hopper is more than an exciting few days at a conference center. It's a place to better understand how the field works, make connections, learn about different job opportunities, and even interview for internships.
  • This is why attending GHC is so important for our students, who attend a small school and live in small cities or towns---places where the focus is on agriculture, not technology. GHC offers opportunities the students won't get anywhere else, and can jumpstart their careers in tech.

I was lucky enough to attend GHC with my own funds. Most of my students are not so lucky. They need your support to attend an event that could lead to a better future for them in tech.

Fundraising details

  • We have funding for transportation, and we may have a funding source for registration fees. However, the high cost of a hotel for all our students can still keep our students from attending, and that is where we're short.
  • We are asking students to contribute approximately $115 each to their conference trip. That leaves a cost of $170 per student for hotel and food over the course of the conference. We have a goal of bringing 7 students, for a total of $1190. So, with the fees that come with Indiegogo, we have set our goal at $1300.
  • Whether or not we reach our entire goal, the funds will go towards sending as many students as possible to GHC.

Other ways you can help

I really appreciate everyone's enthusiasm about this project. If you can't donate, ask your friends if they would be interested. I know there's more than one software engineer out there with a bit of extra money looking for a good home. This is an incredibly direct way to help underrepresented students have a better future in technology, for themselves and for their families.

Note: We are a non-profit :)

Our paperwork for a local Women in CS non-profit is currently making its way through the IRS. If desired, we'll make sure to get your address so we can send the appropriate tax information.

story:
The HackCville Student Staff


Who we are

HackCville is a student-run 501(c)(3) nonprofit that offers skills classes and career development programs for students at the University of Virginia. We provide students with workspace, alumni mentorship, and resources for them to pursue their passions. All of this takes place in our clubhouse, located right next to Grounds on the Corner.

In the spirit of student self-governance, our community is run entirely by and for undergraduate students from across majors and years. We are independent from UVA, and so we rely on alumni, parents, and friends to support the cost of our space and programs each year.


What we do

Just this past semester, we held nearly 60 talks, classes, and workshops, with topics ranging from web development to design to video production. (That’s 60 events in 120 days!)  Many of these skills aren’t taught at UVA, but are still in high demand by today’s employers.

Over 1,000 students come through our doors for our events each year. All of these events are produced by students or by one of our 40+ partner organizations from across UVA and Charlottesville.

We also provide creative working space and resources for students working on passion projects and startups of their own.


30 student entrepreneurship leaders from 5 universities visited HackCville in Sept. 2014


Why we’re crowdfunding

We are an independent, student-run nonprofit that's not affiliated with UVA. We do receive some financial support from UVA departments and grants. However, we are still primarily dependent on support from our donors to keep the lights on and run our programs. We need your help so we can continue to impact thousands of students from across UVA each year.


What your money goes to

Your contributions will go to support 2 key HackCville initiatives for 2015:

1) Help us build the Wahoowa Alumni Network to 1,000 people

HackCville runs Wahoowa, an independent network of UVA alumni entrepreneurs. The network is lead in collaboration with alumni city chapter leaders in San Francisco, New York, and Washington DC.


Over 100 students and alumni connect at our NYC meetup in summer 2014


We hold events to connect alumni to alumni and alumni to students throughout the year. Nearly 400 alumni and students attended a Wahoowa event in 2014 in five cities across the country.


We aim to grow the Wahoowa Network to reach 1,000 alumni and students in 2015. We've planned 14 events in 8 cities including Austin, Boston, LA, SF, NYC, Seattle, DC, and Charlottesville.

Your money will help us cover the venue, food, drink, and marketing costs of these events. This will help us continue to grow the alumni startup community and provide more students with the mentorship they need.


A packed house for our digital user interface and experience, taught by local startup Coshx Labs


2) Help us continue to run dozens of classes, workshops and career programs

As described above, we hold classes and workshops for 1,000+ students each year. Our classes build on what students learn at UVA and better prepare them to become competitive applicants for today’s most innovative companies.

We're extremely excited to continue providing dozens of these events to our students in 2015. Your money will help us cover the costs of our space, food, and marketing materials, enabling us to continue to impact hundreds of students this year.



What you get

We’ve prepared an incredible array of perks. Many of them are created/donated by our own student members at HackCville, including:

  • A limited-edition HackCville t-shirt, designed by incredible 3rd-year designer Anna Cai ($25). 

  • Cupcakes from Norah McDonald, a HackCville member who runs her own bakery ($35)

  • A photography session (personal or event) from one of the talented student photographers at HackCville Media, our in-house publication ($50)

  • A signed copy of Without Their Permission, a book written by reddit co-founder, UVA alum, and proud HackCville supporter Alexis Ohanian ($75)

  • A private tasting of either small batch ultra-premium tequilas (4 expressions of Tequila Ocho) or fine old French Cognacs (4 expressions of Leopold Raffin) from Altamar Brands.

This is just a few of the perks we have available - check out the full list on the right!


Students at a figure drawing workshop at HackCville’s first 12-hour arts creative lock-in


Risks & Challenges

We're confident we can continue to run dozens of classes and programs for our members each semester. We held 60 in fall 2014 alone - we've done it before, and we can do it again. Your support helps us cover our costs.

We held five events for the Wahoowa Alumni Network in 2014. Holding 14 events in additional cities is ambitious, be we are confident we can make it happen. We have strong alumni and student contacts in each of these cities that we can count on to hold these events. We also have support from WeWork, which has graciously offered their space for us to use in each of these cities.


Everything at HackCville is run by students, for students.

Together we've built a growing community that supports self-directed learning and student-led entrepreneurship education at the University of Virginia. We would love to have your support!


Other ways you can help

If you can't support us through our crowdfunding campaign, we'd still love for you to get involved with HackCville in other ways:

  • Learn more about us on our website

  • Subscribe to our newsletter

  • Host an event - contact alex@hackcville.com

  • Attend a Wahoowa event - subscribe for updates

Have another idea? Get in touch: hello@hackcville.com

story:
KATE 1.0 or Kids Avatar Teacher and Entertainer is the ultimate in Disruptive technology for the home, school or lab being it is a  IoT cloud robot and a self contained or tele operated humanoid robot, and KATE is the ultimate in Wearables if a kid or adult needs a hug from a distance, or just needs a hug.

My original idea in 2012 for KATE 1.0 humanoid was to build a robot that men and women parent's far away in a distant lands serving there country in the US military could use KATE 1.0 as a Tele operated robots to play games with there kids, teach there kids, or just give them a big hug from the front lines while on duty.

Another idea at the same time I was building KATE 1.0 was I think KATE would be a big help in interacting with kids with Autism and learning disability's and could help them increase their social interaction skills and communication and learning from young to old.

As a former caretaker I also think KATE humanoids could be use in nursing homes to help patients with Alzheimer's or just a great companion for the lonely living at home. I was also a caretaker for over 10 years for my mom so I know the in's and out's of elderly patient care to be programmed into a Avatar robot AI sub systems, plus I want to have in KATE 1.0 ver2 a Bluetooth pendent or bracelet for the elderly to wear to call KATE for assistance at any time.

KATE 1.0 is a humanoid robot for kids to adults was a quick 4-month project that started on April 2010 for fun. KATE is an autonomous robot as well as a Tele operated robot a cloud robot that never stops learning, a cloud robot. I can see you, I can hear you, I can smell dangerous gases and smoke from fires, and I can talk to you and express emotions, lots of smiles and if needed a hug.

I have an 8 inch Android table for teleconferences and a touch input screen for teaching screen for the young. I have a 22 DOF or degrees of freedom of movement for my body so fare and will be upgraded to more DOF's as well I have a fully articulated mouth that can show emotions of happy or sadness and my lips move also when I talk to express realness.

I have a nose that will sense invisible gases we can't like carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, natural gas, temperature, humidity and smoke from a fire to keep you and your family safe with more sensors to be added to the final model ver 2 of KATE 1.0.

KATE 1.0 is not limited to the English language being see is a cloud robot she will be able to convert to any language at anytime  with ease, I also want her to do sign language for the deaf with new hand designs in KATE 1.0 ver 2 of her.

I use the Microsoft Kinect sensor for motion detection and image depth processing and have sonar sensors for distance sensing also. I also have stereo vision for video conferencing and image processing and I can see I the dark with inferred sensors as well in smoke filled room if there was a fire to help people get out of a burning home.

My robot unique rubber track system is very powerful and can move on all surfaces as well as on steep inclines and outdoors. For my KATE 1.0 brains I use the Intel Atom 450 microprocessor that was donated by Intel running at 1.5 Ghz with Windows XPe and various other embedded software AI components, this will be upgraded to the also Intel donated i5 dual core board 2.5 Ghz running Win 7e with various ROS, AI and CV software.

Inside KATE 1.0 is a few Atmel micro-controllers like the ATMega 168 and ATMega 2560 for multi sensor input functions like accelerometers, gyros and the nose sensor assembly and motion control, also a few Microchip A/D converters and TI and Linear devices voltage regulators, there is other unique parts but best to keep them secret at this time.

I also have 30 channel GPS to not get lost out doors, and soon Solar panels will be added for long duration outside use in the front and back yard or on the go.

KATE 1.0 ver 2 will be upgrade to the newer Intel i5 dual core 2.5 Ghz highly embedded low power board that was also donated by Intel corp for the robot project earlier this year, Intel is an embedded partner for all my humanoid projects. The KATE 1.0 ver 2 will have the latest in new technology's, KATE 1.0 as you see her is a prototype and the final version will be even more fantastic and even more friendly and functional. Join me, lets make KATE 1.0 a reality. 

                                Kate in the Tech News.
KATE 1.0 humanoid project in the new CNET magazine July 24, 2012
KATE 1.0 humanoid project in the new HiZook magazine, April 16, 2012
KATE 1.0 humanoid in Plastic Pals robotics magazine, April 18, 2012
KATE 1.0 featured in IEEE magazine, April 27, 2012
My KATE humanoid was included in this PhD robot dissertation:


KATE 1.0 mechanical Specs


 
Size
Height: 45 inches tall
Width: 18 inches
Depth: 18 inches
Weight: 70 Lbs.
Performance
Travel speed: 3 to 8 mph.
Li-Po Battery Time:
(Walking)		 2.5 to 4 hours.
Degrees of Freedom
Head: 7
Arm: 2 × 2
Hand: 4 × 2
Torso: 1
Leg: 1 × 2
TOTAL 22
What's inside KATE 1.0 humanoid robot,
These are basic specs. and can change anytime to be upgraded to more advanced system parts.
KATE 1.0 will be able to tell if your Happy, or Sad or not feeling well Medical sensing using the latest in 3 D Microsoft Kinect technology, KATE  not only has the 3D Kinect technology, she also has Stereo vision in her head for even more interaction in her environment, KATE 1.0 has 3 CCD cameras, 2 in the head unit, and 1 in the Kinect and one 3D camera in the Kinect and 6 microphones to hear her environment, with sonar and the she has the latest hand gesters motion technology's also.
                        Some 3D vision examples below of what KATE 1.0 will see.




Specifications and capabilities:


OS Win Xpe now, with Windows 7e in ver 2 of KATE 1.0
CPU's Intel Atom - 1.50 Ghz processor, and Arduino micro-controllers.
Being upgraded to Intel i5 dual core 2.5 Ghz low power embedded board
Vision system
Microsoft Kinect + Stereo color Vision with
Depth Perception,  KATE 1.0 ver 2 will use the latest Microsoft Kinect sensor.
BODY
Aluminum, Steel
Plastic, Rubber
Sensors Various Gas sensors,
multi 3-Axis Accelerometers
Multi Ultrasonic range units
6 microphones
Actuators DC PM Servo Motor
Reduction Mechanism Gear Box + RC servos
Power Dual 12 volt 18 amp, Li-Po-Fe batterys
Cost KATE was built with off the shelf parts and modified them.








ABOUT ME:

Dan Mathias - CTO Robotics Scientist and Robotics visionary at

FutureBots Humanoid labs
I'm the owner and founder of FutureBots in 1985 with a few disciplines in Electrical engineering, Mechanical engineering, Computer science, and Software engineering, Robot builder to name a few with over 35 years of real world engineering experience.  FutureBots went full time in 1992 it's an electronic components company specializing in robotic component parts for the hobbyist and professional for the last 29 years. The company was founded in 1985 after I built my first humanoid mobile robot George. I decided there was a need for a company to sell various parts like computer chips, motors, and robot body parts to the public that was building and experimenting with electronics and robotics. 

KATE 1.0 and Dan Mathias Robotics Scientist

     My Small Robotics Lab

ABOUT:
FutureBots Humanoid Lab - FBHL " We are Building Tomorrow, Today". We maybe small but we have BIG ideas.
Dan Mathias a Robotics Scientist, CEO, Visionary and Extreme Maker at FutureBots.com. A hands on thinking out of the box Engineer having 35+ years of private sector experience.
I have been building robots since the early 1980's. Skills like building fiberglass Boats, Molds, building Restaurant interiors, and Epoxy table tops. Building and driving Race cars, Engine and Chassis building, or working at a Major Semiconductor company on advanced Space and Military rated parts as a Senior Test and Design Engineer, or building robots and circuits since I was 15 with a vast knowledge of IC's, Micro's and 12 years of various engineering college degrees. My resume on LinkedIn.

                                          Some of my early robot creations

For me robotics is my passion since I was 10, my dad instilled in me a passion for engineering, I have built many robots and taken apart thousands of computers and printers, radios, TV's to see how they worked, even if I don't get the funding I need I will still build robots, but today to really make things happen we need cash flow and lots of it to stay ahead of the Google's that are taking over all tech devices, please help me make the KATE 1.0 project come alive, thanks.

The funding of $200,000 is kinda a minimum to make the KATE 1.0 project happen, rent on a new large robotics lab with office and manufacturing area with utility's for 3 years would cost some $50k to $70k for some 6000 square feet, buying a couple high end 3D printers and a high end 3 axis mill maybe cost another $30k+, buying all the plastics and electronics and hardware parts another $30K+ and hire a few engineers, interns and techs another $50k+ or more, does not leave much for squiggle room, but I have to try, to get the KATE 1.0 off the ground needs funding and that's why I'm here.
$500k to a 1 million would be optimal to really make things happen, but time will tell on all of the funding here, this is very new to me. even if I don't reach my goal I will find a way, there is no turning back, just imagine a KATE 1.0 in every home teaching kids, helping adults, maybe even walk the dog.
Your probably wondering what KATE 1.0 would cost to sell, I want to keep KATE 1.0  under $5,000 and in the range of maybe $3500 to $4000 as we gear up production, for that price you are getting a great amount of technology.

The Impact

KATE 1.0 will be the first full size humanoid for house use that will out perform all others that yet exist, there is None in the USA yet, not even Google has a intelligent home tele operated cloud humanoid yet, lets beat them to the punch and get this project funded plus some and going.

The KATE 1.0 humanoid project will make jobs, help kids and adults, and also would be a great tool in the robot labs around the country being KATE is semi open source for hardware and software. KATE 1.0 uses off the self parts to make manufacturing a ease.

KATE 1.0 is not the only humanoid coming from the FutureBots Humanoid Lab there is also the ATOM 1.0 a full size humanoid being developed for the hard work to support the needs of mankind in Space exploration, Healthcare, Commercial and Industrial Manufacturing, Hazardous rescue activities and Chemical and Biological disposal applications.

My ATOM 1.0 full-size humanoid is also entered in the DRC - DARPA challenge for mid 2015, we are 1 of only 17 teams entered. ATOM 1.0 Humanoid featured on the DARPA DRC site entered in the event 08/25/2014.

ATOM 1.0 is a 8 year part-time project that is about ready to walk, he is 5'3" tall @ 185 lbs, just imagine KATE humanoids working inside houses while ATOM humanoids do the dangerous hard work outside keeping us safe.

                 ATOM 1.0 Humanoid from the FutureBots Humanoid Lab.


Risks & Challenges

Even with funding it's a hard road, but just look at what I have built with NO funding KATE 1.0 and ATOM 1.0 and many other robots, just imagine what I could think up and make to create jobs and prosperity again in the USA and in that process helping the young to the old in need, I'm a go getter, I always find a way around any problem, my dad Calvin worked at Pratt & Whitney as a engineer  and taught me how to solve engineering problems.

There will be 10's of millions of elderly in the next decade and now that will need help at home and to have just some company to play checkers, remind to take there medicine or go to a doctors appointment or even help them in there exercises, one reason I built KATE and ATOM was for the kids and elderly in need, they need are help.

I was a caretaker a few years back so I know what the elderly need to comfort them, please help me make this dream come true so we can help them. 

A few years back in the mid 1970's when I was a teen there was a person named Bill Gates III and Steve Jobs or Dell or HP started with a small dream in a garage and now look at what it has created all around us technological prosperity, my FutureBots Humanoid Lab may be small at this time but we have BIG ideas, please help, let do it together, thanks!.


Other Ways You Can Help and Perks

Please spread the word on social media about the KATE 1.0 humanoid project, all help is needed and appreciated, lets work together to make this dream happen. Thanks !

Just a idea example of the KATE 1.0 T-Shirt, Plaque, Sticker and Car plate will look like, the final version will be great.

KATE 1.0 wooden Plaque.

    

KATE 1.0 plastic car sticker 10 x 2 inches.

KATE 1.0 car license plate.


A thanks card in the mail.
story_txt:
KATE 1.0 or Kids Avatar Teacher and Entertainer is the ultimate in Disruptive technology for the home, school or lab being it is a  IoT cloud robot and a self contained or tele operated humanoid robot, and KATE is the ultimate in Wearables if a kid or adult needs a hug from a distance, or just needs a hug. My original idea in 2012 for KATE 1.0 humanoid was to build a robot that men and women parent's far away in a distant lands serving there country in the US military could use KATE 1.0 as a Tele operated robots to play games with there kids, teach there kids, or just give them a big hug from the front lines while on duty. 
Another idea at the same time I was building KATE 1.0 was I think KATE would be a big help in interacting with kids with Autism and learning disability's and could help them increase their social interaction skills and communication and learning from young to old. As a former caretaker I also think KATE humanoids could be use in nursing homes to help patients with Alzheimer's or just a great companion for the lonely living at home. I was also a caretaker for over 10 years for my mom so I know the in's and out's of elderly patient care to be programmed into a Avatar robot AI sub systems, plus I want to have in KATE 1.0 ver2 a Bluetooth pendent or bracelet for the elderly to wear to call KATE for assistance at any time.
KATE 1.0 is a humanoid robot for kids to adults was a quick 4-month project that started on April 2010 for fun. KATE is an autonomous robot as well as a Tele operated robot a cloud robot that never stops learning, a cloud robot. I can see you, I can hear you, I can smell dangerous gases and smoke from fires, and I can talk to you and express emotions, lots of smiles and if needed a hug. 
I have an 8 inch Android table for teleconferences and a touch input screen for teaching screen for the young. I have a 22 DOF or degrees of freedom of movement for my body so fare and will be upgraded to more DOF's as well I have a fully articulated mouth that can show emotions of happy or sadness and my lips move also when I talk to express realness. 
I have a nose that will sense invisible gases we can't like carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, natural gas, temperature, humidity and smoke from a fire to keep you and your family safe with more sensors to be added to the final model ver 2 of KATE 1.0.KATE 1.0 is not limited to the English language being see is a cloud robot she will be able to convert to any language at anytime  with ease, I also want her to do sign language for the deaf with new hand designs in KATE 1.0 ver 2 of her.
I use the Microsoft Kinect sensor for motion detection and image depth processing and have sonar sensors for distance sensing also. I also have stereo vision for video conferencing and image processing and I can see I the dark with inferred sensors as well in smoke filled room if there was a fire to help people get out of a burning home. 
My robot unique rubber track system is very powerful and can move on all surfaces as well as on steep inclines and outdoors. For my KATE 1.0 brains I use the Intel Atom 450 microprocessor that was donated by Intel running at 1.5 Ghz with Windows XPe and various other embedded software AI components, this will be upgraded to the also Intel donated i5 dual core board 2.5 Ghz running Win 7e with various ROS, AI and CV software. Inside KATE 1.0 is a few Atmel micro-controllers like the ATMega 168 and ATMega 2560 for multi sensor input functions like accelerometers, gyros and the nose sensor assembly and motion control, also a few Microchip A/D converters and TI and Linear devices voltage regulators, there is other unique parts but best to keep them secret at this time.I also have 30 channel GPS to not get lost out doors, and soon Solar panels will be added for long duration outside use in the front and back yard or on the go. KATE 1.0 ver 2 will be upgrade to the newer Intel i5 dual core 2.5 Ghz highly embedded low power board that was also donated by Intel corp for the robot project earlier this year, Intel is an embedded partner for all my humanoid projects. The KATE 1.0 ver 2 will have the latest in new technology's, KATE 1.0 as you see her is a prototype and the final version will be even more fantastic and even more friendly and functional. Join me, lets make KATE 1.0 a reality.                                  Kate in the Tech News.KATE 1.0 humanoid project in the new CNET magazine July 24, 2012KATE 1.0 humanoid project in the new HiZook magazine, April 16, 2012 KATE 1.0 humanoid in Plastic Pals robotics magazine, April 18, 2012KATE 1.0 featured in IEEE magazine, April 27, 2012
My KATE humanoid was included in this PhD robot dissertation: 


 KATE 1.0 mechanical Specs 







 


Size

 45 inches tall

18 inches




Depth:
18 inches

70 Lbs.



Performance



Travel speed:
3 to 8 mph.

Degrees of Freedom

7

TOTAL

What's inside KATE 1.0 humanoid robot,  These are basic specs. and can change anytime to be upgraded to more advanced system parts.
KATE 1.0 will be able to tell if your Happy, or Sad or not feeling well Medical sensing using the latest in 3 D Microsoft Kinect technology, KATE  not only has the 3D Kinect technology, she also has Stereo vision in her head for even more interaction in her environment, KATE 1.0 has 3 CCD cameras, 2 in the head unit, and 1 in the Kinect and one 3D camera in the Kinect and 6 microphones to hear her environment, with sonar and the she has the latest hand gesters motion technology's also.                        Some 3D vision examples below of what KATE 1.0 will see.






Specifications and capabilities: 



OS
Win Xpe now, with Windows 7e in ver 2 of KATE 1.0




CPU's
Intel Atom - 1.50 Ghz processor, and Arduino micro-controllers.Being upgraded to Intel i5 dual core 2.5 Ghz low power embedded board



Vision system 

Microsoft Kinect + Stereo color Vision with  Depth Perception,  KATE 1.0 ver 2 will use the latest Microsoft Kinect sensor.




BODY


Aluminum, Steel 
Plastic, Rubber





Sensors
Various Gas sensors, multi 3-Axis Accelerometers Multi Ultrasonic range units 6 microphones 


Actuators
DC PM Servo Motor


Reduction Mechanism
Gear Box + RC servos


Power
Dual 12 volt 18 amp, Li-Po-Fe batterys


Cost
 KATE was built with off the shelf parts and modified them.

 in 1985 with a few disciplines in Electrical engineering,  Mechanical 
engineering, Computer science, and  Software engineering, Robot builder 
to name a few with over 35 years of real world engineering experience.  FutureBots  went full time in 1992 
it's an electronic components company specializing in robotic component 
parts for the hobbyist and professional for the last 29 years. The 
company was founded in 1985 after I built my first humanoid mobile robot
 George. I decided there was a need for a company to sell various parts 
like computer chips, motors, and robot body parts to the public that was
 building and experimenting with electronics and robotics. 
KATE 1.0 and Dan Mathias Robotics Scientist

     My Small Robotics Lab

Skills like building fiberglass Boats, Molds, building Restaurant interiors, and Epoxy table tops. story:
Special Friends –

Most of you know that I am in my fourth year on the Advisory Board of Oasis For Girls, a wonderful project of the Tides Center.  Our mission is to partner with over 150 Girls annually from under-resourced communities in San Francisco to help them cultivate the skills, knowledge, and confidence to discover their dreams and build strong futures. 

Our impact continues to increase!  The Advisory Board is currently raising $5,000 to provide stipends for even more Girls this coming year.  Toward this goal, I have committed to raise a minimum of $1,000 and hope you will consider a contribution.  No donation is too small!

Oasis programs provide a safe space to enable Girls to develop behavioral and critical thinking, expressive and academic leadership, and job readiness skills to maximize their potential for success.  Program stipends range from $300 - $500 to ensure that the Girls who need us most are able to participate.  

The work of Oasis For Girls is absolutely essential to mind the gap and lift up low-income, young women of color in under-resourced communities in San Francisco.

  • We are the only Girl serving after-high school program offering life skills, creative arts education, and career exploration in San Francisco.
  • Many of the Girls are dabbling with difficulty. Some are first generation immigrants, in the foster care system, active in the juvenile justice system, struggling with or confused about their sexual orientation, or not achieving in school. Oasis provides a safe space for them to explore their identity, express themselves, and build strong friendships with peers and adult female mentors.
  • Stipends primarily support basic needs including food, clothes, transportation costs, and school supplies.  Funding also supports access beyond their immediate communities to all that SF has to offer, including varied activities and high-profile company site visits.

Oasis is a small organization with tremendous impact.  All of the money raised goes directly to the Oasis Girls.  Many thanks for your support!

-- Juanita

story:
Fugees Academy is a program of Fugees Family, Inc. a non-profit organization working with child survivors of war to realize their vast potential.  We need to raise $27,750 to cover the tuition of 6 new students next year, and we need your help. You have the power to transform a child' life. Please give today.


We’re excited to share that Indigo Girls Amy Ray and Emily Saliers are generously supporting our campaign by providing special gifts to all donors! Please join with Amy and Emily and lend your support. Help us move 6 more children from being refugees to being Fugees!

Fugees Academy is the nation’s only school dedicated to refugee education.  We are focused on meeting the unique needs of refugee children so they can flourish and succeed in their new home. Since our founding in 2008, our student body has grown from 6 students to 91 students. These students come from 39 different countries. All speak English as a second language, live below the poverty level and have experienced the trauma of war.

Why is Fugees Academy Needed?

The Fugees Academy serves a pressing need – the education of refugee children in an environment that understands their unique academic challenges.

Refugees are resettled in the United States after they have been forced to flee their homeland because of war or persecution. Often, there is a long waiting period between the time refugees leave their homes and the time they are granted entry to the United States. Generally, this interim time is spent in refugee camps, where the obstacles to survival and safety have been well-documented, and formal education for children is neither a priority nor an option. As such, when they do finally arrive in the United States, refugee students enter school behind their American-born peers – both academically and socio-emotionally – given that many of them have not had any formal schooling, and most have lived through traumatic circumstances. Further, they have no one at home to help, since their parents are usually illiterate in both their native language and English. Lacking the support and guidance they need to succeed in traditional public schools, too many refugee children fail to learn English, develop fundamental academic skills, or identify themselves as a valuable part of American society.

Student Transformation 

At the Fugees Academy, students find a bridge from isolation to socialization and learning. Our programming has demonstrated that in a highly structured environment where rules and expectations are clear, and creativity and individuality are nurtured, refugee children not only catch up – they become stellar performers who can meet rigorous academic standards.

Graduating the First High School Senior Class!

The school is now in its seventh year, and has received SAIS and SACS accreditation. Starting as a middle school, the Academy now serves students in grades 6-11 and is on track to graduate its first high school senior class in 2016!

The Fugees Family:  Building On The Power of Soccer

Ten years ago, Coach Luma Mufleh started a Fugees team to provide refugee boys with free access to organized soccer. Since then, the organization’s programming has grown to include year-round soccer for 90 boys and girls aged 10-18, after-school tutoring, soccer for 50 elementary-aged students, an academic enrichment summer camp, and the Fugees Academy.

Your Donation is Tax-Deductible

Fugees Family, Inc. is a 501 (C) (3) non-profit organization. Your donation is tax-deductible to the full extent of the law.

story:
About this project: E-LEARNING|GAME LEARNING about wine... We offer a learning method for wine enthusiasts, Do you want to expand your knowledge of wine in a fun and appealing, yet serious way?  

“Learn and practise in the comfort of your own home”

This  program offers you an interactive digital learning program for wine knowledge. This is a perfect preparation for the official Dutch wine certificate SWEN (‘Stichting Wijn Examens Nederland’) or the international WSET (Wine and Spirits Education Trust) Level 2-3. 


Are you willing to help us to increase wine knowledge in the world?  

The demand for education in wine is strongly increasing because more and more people want to have some knowledge about wine. Wine Training Online caters to this demand by offering a platform for accessing a wide variety of information about wine. It is an interactive platform where wine enthusiasts can find background information about many wine-related topics. Wine Training Online also offers an interactive E-Learning | Game Learning programme. Wine Training Online uses modern digital learning methods like E-learning, game learning, and mobile learning and aims to expand knowledge of wine in collaboration with several strategic business partners.

Wine Training Online is available in several languages.

E-LEARNING | GAME LEARNING offers a learning method for wine enthusiasts who want to expand their knowledge of wine in a fun and appealing, yet serious way. Emphasis is on ease of use and application of innovative modern techniques. 

  • We offer you a Online training in 12 modules. 
  • Practice whenever you want it: "at home, the office, or a holiday address" 
  •  24/7 available.
Preview: Dutch

The Impact
Wine Training Online is already available in Dutch, German and English language and will be available in Chinese language on a separate platform. E-Learning | Game Learning and Mobile Learning have a number of strengths apart from the ‘entertainment’ aspect:

    1. By presenting certain information and/or skills as games, we make it fun to learn, discover, and experience. The user stays motivated and will retain new knowledge longer.

    2. Everyone can gain knowledge and experience at their own pace.

    3. Every user receives customised information and feedback. The learning method is unconventional and has been proven to work.

    4. The games are created by a team of experienced game designers and experts in learning methods and education.

    5. The contents of a programme should of course fit learning goal(s) and contain the desired knowledge and interactive possibilities.

    6. Visual design plays an important role. The games are appealing and, because of their professional interface, users will instantly know what they are supposed to do.

If you like this fund but you are not a wine lover, There are other Ways You Can Help...

If you like this fund but you are not a wine lover... Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Send Winetraining Online giftbox to a college -friend or familie "Wine lover" 
  • Just support us to reach our goals and and participate for EUR 7,50
  • You can share this with your friend on social media and the Indiegogo share tools!

I really thank you for your support! 

Ruud Weterings RV
