story:
WE STILL NEED YOUR HELP! WE are InDemand!

WE have reached the goal of Repairing the Roof! But we still need your help to continue the projects we have started!

We are Radu Apostol (director), Katia Pascariu (actress), Mihaela Michailov (playwright), Viorel Cojanu (actor) and Mihaela Radescu (actress). We are the founders of The Replika Center for Educational Theater, which opened its doors to the public on February 13th, 2015 in Tineretului neighborhood, Bucharest.

The space was conceived as an independent, interdisciplinary space, promoting the collaboration between professional artists and members of vulnerable communities and encouraging a theater for young audience, deeply involved in our society.

The Replika Center for Educational Theater is a collaborative space, where the team is involved in all the activities, from designing artistic programs to welcoming the audience, from fundraising to cleaning the toilets.

Our Vision

We strongly believe in mutual education through artistic means, in art as a form of empowering ignored social groups, voicing their needs and expectations. We believe in the activist artist, mirroring the society and transgressing our realities, we believe in educational utopias becoming reality, in pedagogy as a shared process of raising community stories, in a theater based on cooperation and respect for everybody’s story.

 

We support free access to cultural education as a fundamental right, expanding the access to culture for vulnerable categories disconnected from contemporary art. This is why all our events are free and this is why we want to tell their stories.

Replika Center is located in Tineretului neighborhood, a well known area for the activism of the inhabitants gathered in different communities to protect animal welfare or public parks&nature.  

 

What We Have Achieved

A year after its inception, The Replika Center for Educational Theater organized 2 Educational Art Platforms, featuring 17 shows, with more than 80 artists involved, 21 presentations of books and studies  and 21 film screenings.

At The Replika Center for Educational Theater, in only one year, we produced 7 premieres, we organized 4 workshops with children and teenagers and more than 8000 spectators took part in our events.

 

 

 

 

Our impact and outreach goes beyond Bucharest with many  theater performances  presented on tour in Romania. We showed The Offline Family by Mihaela Michailov, performance which reflects the reality of children living on their own having their parents working abroad, in major cities from Transylvania (Bra?ov, Târgu Mure?, Sfântu Gheorghe, Media?, Sibiu, Alba Iulia) along with workshops on educational theater.

Confessions of a Dog, based on Peter Mayle's novel and a Civic Educational Workshop on animal welfare, went on tour in cities with history of bad treatment towards the animals:  Bac?u, Boto?ani, F?lticeni, Pa?cani, Piatra Neam?, Roman, Suceava, Târgu Neam?, Târgu Frumos and Foc?ani.

Our recent premiere In your own words by Peca ?tefan, was on tour in Br?ila, Sibiu and Cluj. Each premiere from last season was invited at Temps d'Images International Theater Festival Cluj Napoca.

Our work has already been recognized by AFCN (The National Culture Fund) who offered us in January 2016 the Award for Social inclusion and Intercultural Dialogue. In March 2016 we were nominated at The Award for Cultural Programs and Festivals offered by The National Cultural Radio station.

 

Our Community

But perhaps our greatest achievement was the large community we have brought together in our projects. 
Since its opening, thanks to its generous and versatile space characteristics (length&height, plenty possibilities to arrange the audience),  Replika Center gathered  many artists from the performative arts field. Thanks to our Educational Art Platforms, Replika Center became  a space where new films meet their audiences. Thanks to its location in a neighborhood from Bucharest, Replika Center hosted public meetings of the social activists.

 

Our community consists now of teenagers, teachers and parents, of people from the neighbourhood,  of students and adults who became more than our public, but our partners.  We are grateful and happy for their interest  - they came once and then they kept coming to our programs - performances and workshops.
We collaborated with many artists and we thank them for being part of the Replika Center community:

Arh Gabi Albu, Cristian Bala?, Alexa B?canu, Robert B?lan, C?t?lina B?l?l?u, Alexandru Berceanu, Alexandru Bibere, Miki Brani?te, M?d?lina Brându?e, Bogdan Burl?cianu, Andreea Chindri?, Ionu? Corpaci, Carmen Co?ofan?, C?t?lin Cre?u, Paul Dunca, Farid Fairuz, ?tefania Ferched?u, Carmen Florescu, M?d?lina Florescu, Elena G?geanu, Florina Gleznea, Sabina Gr?dinaru, Adela Iacoban, Andreea Iacomi??, Sabrina Ia?chevici, Adi Iclenzan, Stanca Jabe?ian, Sânziana Koenig, Ioana Macarie, Cosmin Manolescu, Radu Manelici, Oana Mardare, Sebastian Marina, Monica Marinescu, Ana M?rgineanu, Lala Mi?osniky, Lucian Moga, Ionu? Niculae, Jak Neumann, Peca ?tefan, Iasmina Petrovici, Liviu Popa, Leta Popescu, Alexandru Potocean, Oana Pu?catu, George Rotaru, C?t?lin Rulea, David Schwartz, Ionu? Sociu, Raul St?nulescu, Andrei ?erban, Nico Vaccari, Vava ?tef?nescu, Doru Talo?, Victor ??peanu, Elena Vl?d?reanu, Dana Voicu, Marius Bogdan Tudor, Vlad Cristian Zamfir, Elise Wilk and many more.

Our Plans Going Forward

What we intend to do is to both continue our programs and to start new projects like the one we called RAR - Artistic Residences at Replika. If we obtain the grants we have applied for, in 2016 we will have 3 artistic residencies, inviting artists from Bucharest, Cluj and the US.

Contemporary Dance and Kites. Choreographer Cosmin Manolescu will develop a series of workshops for children, followed by a dance performance.

Pop-Up Theatrics (New York) will develop the first stage of a theatrical project called Altered Perception, an artistic exploration of the challenges and benefits of sense impairment.

And from Cluj, director Leta Popescu and playwright Alexa B?canu, two young voices of Romanian Theater, in partnership with CEDP Step by Step will develop the first phase of a theatrical project that will explore the perspectives and implications of Sexual Education for children in Romania.

Each residency will end up in 2017 with a theater performance.

During 2016 we will be part of the IndependNet Platform, an exchange cultural program imagined by our partners from Cluj - Reactor de Crea?ie ?i Experiment. This means that Replika team will tour in Târgu Mure? and Cluj Napoca, and will host theater performances created by its partners from Colectiv A and ZugZone, both from Cluj.

By the end of this season we plan to host four premiers: director Ioana P?un will stage a performance based on the outrageous untold histories of Romanian torturers during the Cold War; director Catinca Dr?g?nescu will develop a theater performance about the condition of women forced to work abroad, leaving their children alone back home; dramAcum will develop a theater performance based on contemporary Turkish plays; director Mihai Ion Alexandru will stage a theater performance based on the novel Kremlin Made Of Sugar by Vladimir Sorokin. 

 

In September and October 2016 we will go on tour with Our Daily Hunger, a play developed by Peca ?tefan, directed by Ana M?rgineanu and Radu Apostol, performing in 7 different locations in Romania.

Starting from September till November we will continue our Educational Art Platform, presenting theater performances, books and movies.

   

What We Need

Due to its previous use as a warehouse, the building needs certain improvements in order to adequately host theater work and live audiences. Particularly, the roof is in a bad shape and allows water to infiltrate the building with every rain or snowfall. This situation made us suspend our activities altogether last winter. Because we still have to pay the rent and the utilities, regardless of not using the venue, such periods of inactivity are very damaging to our project and to our audiences and community. Repairing the roof has become our main priority and we estimate that we need 8000$ in order to do it.

This total cost consists of:

?  doing a professional assessment of the roof’s state

?  purchasing the necessary materials

?  waterproofing and thermal insulating

?  hiring a contractor

If we manage to raise more money than 8000$, we would use it to improve the building’s ventilation system and invest in lighting and sound equipment that was by the rain, thus improving the space and the experience of our audiences.

Your help and your financial support are essential for us, for continuing a project that managed to draw the interest of the people in the district, of kids and teenagers, of teachers and artists. No amount is too small!

What You Get

We have a lot of special rewards to offer for your support.  As all of our donors will receive our eternal gratitude and will become friends of the venue, some of you could receive a real interaction with a character from a Replika show, get to create a line that will be used in the next production or even be our guest to a rehearsal.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help us spread the information about our campaign to all your friends. Use the Indiegogo share tools and be a part of our community of roof builders!

Donate for the space, donate for the roof. The space belongs to those who build it up.

Big thanks to Ada Milea, Ion Mure?an, Bobo Burl?cianu, Cristi Rigman who have generously offered us the song "Acoperi?ul" and to Kolectiv, Bogdan Sl?vescu (camera) and Roger Vl?doianu (editor) for the video.

We would also like to thank to Goethe-Guerilla, a program initiated by Goethe-Institut Bucharest, for the collaboration.

  Let’s raise the roof at REPLIKA!


Pentru versiunea în limba român? accesa?i link-ul:
https://tmblr.co/ZgNrhv24TFzJk

story:
Short Summary

Laura dedicated a lot of time, and a not inconsiderable amount of her own money into organising an event for the Kiama High School Class of 2003 10 year Reunion. On the response to early information, Laura expected a turn out of up to 200 guests and booked a venue and package accordingly. Now it's crunch time and Laura has to pay the venue and only has ~40 confirmed guests! 

This campaign is simply to help Laura recoup any costs she outlaid on the event from her own pocket, after so many people have backed out of an event they said they would attend.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Depending on how many people commit further, the amount Laura needs to cover costs will vary. The event is too far a long to cancel, so even if you can only spare $5 it will help pay the outstanding $2800 currently owing.
  • If we don't reach our goal, Laura will definitely be out of pocket, but any funds raised will be pushed through to Laura.
  • If enough people contribute we can throw what will surely be a memorable party and any excess funds will be donated to a charity of Laura's choice.
  • For those that said they could make it and have bailed, this is the chance to make up for it, even if you can only spare a few dollars, please donate so we can make this a memorable night for the right reasons.

And that’s all there is to it.

If we don't reach our goal, Laura will definitely be out of pocket, but any funds raised will be pushed through to Laura.
If enough people contribute we can throw what will surely be a memorable party and any excess funds will be donated to a charity of Laura's choice.
For those that said they could make it and have bailed, this is the chance to make up for it, even if you can only spare a few dollars, please donate so we can make this a memorable night for the right reasons.


And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Courageous visionary Tash Bing is planning Zenerjoy Community Retreat - a place of peace, connection and creativity in a stunning natural setting. Tash is turning the heart-rending experiences of her childhood into love and support for others in need.

Support Tash’s entrepreneurial journey by sending her for iLAB Mentoring

.....................................................................................................................

I’m Tash Bing

I have a burning desire to create a legacy of love and support for others. 

My experiences as a young person could have destroyed me. Instead, they taught me to be strong, deeply compassionate and determined. Now I need iLAB mentoring to further develop my entrepreneurial skills, so that my vision for Zenerjoy Community Retreat becomes a reality.

Zenerjoy will change lives. By supporting me, you’re helping real people in real need. 

iLAB Mentoring

iLAB Incubator iLAB Incubator Mentoring is a unique residential 30-day intensive program that offers co-working, training and mentoring for entrepreneurs. 

iLAB will prepare me for launching Zenerjoy.  


iLAB participants

My Story  

My younger brother and I grew up in a family deeply troubled by alcohol and violence.  Our parents, young themselves, married because they were pregnant with me.  

Imagine me as the young girl in Once were Warriors. The difference is that I lived.

I witnessed horrific beatings in my own family. I told others about the fighting, but was always sent back home. All I wanted to do was stop the drinking and end the physical abuse I was a victim of. But I never could. 

Once my mother pushed me out of the car she was driving. She didn’t want to hear my ‘over-simplified solution’ to the problem of what to do about my Dad, who had passed out on someone’s doorstep.  

I became hyper-vigilant, always on the alert for the signs that arguments were escalating into full-blown fights. And my life was threatened many times. 

Me as a child of about 10 

Sexual Abuse and Rape

When I was 13, I was sexually abused. I pretended to be asleep, then cried when he left my room. The second time it happened, I stood up to my abuser and eventually told someone. But my mum hated me more, and my brother and friends thought I was making it up. My parents separated because I’d ‘told’. 

My mother moved us away from the farm, and we lived in poverty in town. Some days we had nothing at all to eat and I never had the right clothes in winter.

When I was 14, I was raped. A cute guy with a car had started taking notice of me. I pretended I was 16 and he pretended he was 18. Actually he was much older. He picked me up to go to the movies, drove me out into the forest, threatened me with a knife, covered my face, and did what he did. He said if I told anyone I would find him hanging on my doorstep. So I didn’t tell. 

Later that year I met my high-school sweetheart. He and his family were nice to me and welcomed me into their home. They had food I’d never seen, and they didn’t argue.

15 and Pregnant

At 15, I was pregnant. Without my parents’ consent, I asked doctors  to sign off to terminate my pregnancy. They were easily persuaded.

At 17 I fell pregnant again. Too afraid to terminate a second time, I hid my pregnancy for as long as I could. My daughter was born 2 months before I turned 18. I didn’t go to prenatal classes and had no idea what to expect. It was a very difficult birth.

Somehow I made my way through a Diploma in Tourism and Travel, and moved to Australia with my high-school sweetheart. We got married, had another baby, and bought a house. 

I followed my husband, and his dreams because it was easy and I felt safe. But in my heart, I knew I wasn’t being true to myself. 

Me at 27 with my son

After 16 years together we separated. It was the hardest decision to make, given the support he and his family had given me over the years. If it wasn’t for them, my life would have taken a different path for sure. 

My Brother

From the age of 16, my brother spent his time on the streets sniffing petrol. One day when he found shelter in an empty shipping container, he ended up getting locked in and shipped from the North Island of New Zealand to Christchurch on the South Island.

Now 37, he’s spent almost 20 years in a mental facility suffering from drug-induced schizophrenia. How he’s survived no one really knows, but at least he has a home. At least he’s safe. 

And Now

I live on the Sunshine Coast in Queensland, Australia. I’m remarried and have two step-children. I’ve spent many years on personal development, and have started a degree in psychology. I love living here. My friendships and connections are amazing. I have a small online jewellery business www.infinitewoman.com.au. It’s very new, and isn’t quite at the stage of helping me financially build my dream. 

My two kids & my husband’s two boys on our wedding day

My Zenerjoy Vision

My commitment and passionate desire to help others come together in a place I call Zenerjoy. Your support will help me realise my goal.

Set amongst the refreshing and lush sub-tropical coast of Queensland, Australia, I imagine a unique place where people gather for profound and unforgettable experiences. This is Zenerjoy Community Retreat. 

Zenerjoy Community Retreat is physically beautiful. There’s a large botanical garden with a labyrinth, and highly productive community gardens where fruits and vegetables are grown. Those who visit the gardens and buy nutritious produce contribute to the financial sustainability of the Retreat. 

The Retreat’s Community Centre offers low-priced meeting spaces, conference rooms and creative arts and woodwork studios. Long and short-term accommodation is available in a Lodge. Visiting facilitators from a range of modalities offer workshops, seminars, retreats and events. Participants develop confidence, potential and motivation as they heal through relaxation, learning and play.

"Everybody needs beauty as well as bread, places to play in and pray in, where nature may heal and give strength to body and soul alike." ~ John Muir

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

How will the funds be used?

•  30-day iLAB Incubator mentorship for entrepreneurs: $7,200.00

•  Misc iLAB costs:  $1,500.00

•  Additional planning and preparation:  $2,000.00

•  Funds for progressing Zenerjoy during iLAB: $10,000.00

•  Indiegogo fees: $xx

•  Total funding goal:  $22,000.00

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

So let’s make it happen.

See below for the perks that come with your contribution and please leave a comment.

Find my Facebook pages 

https://www.facebook.com/Zenerjoy

https://www.facebook.com/infinitewomanonline

https://twitter.com/Zenerjoy

Tweet us @zenerjoy using #gogozenerjoy.

Every bit helps! 

With gratitude, Tash xx

story:
My name is Dominic Luciano. I was born with Cerebral Palsy, and as a child required extensive physical therapy just to walk. Among that therapy was occupational therapy that was aimed at helping me learn to do rudimentary things as no doctor ever thought I would function beyond that. I proved them wrong.

At the age of 2, I was given a small piano. As I grew up, so did the size and complexity of the keyboard. Eventually my left hand opened up and I was able to do things beyond just playing piano (like tie my shoes), all because of the piano

I began taking classical lessons at the age of 6, and did so for about 4 years, until I began to do things like write music and branch out into music production, as well as experiment with other genres.

By the time I entered high school, I had already had two brain surgeries from another condition I was diagnosed with called Neurofibromatosis Type 2. But I continued to play piano and entered the high school jazz band not ever having played a bar of jazz.

One month later, I was named Best High School Jazz Piano Soloist in the entire state of Oregon; the only freshman from my high school to win an award so big. The next year as a sophomore, I won the winter talent show (basically a popularity contest) with a rendition of "Greensleeves", upsetting the competition and becoming, in all humility, a legend for all of my accomplishments in the two years I was in high school.

I then entered college at 15 years old, received two degrees by the time I was 19, taught a middle school jazz band for two years when Medford School District 549C cancelled the middle school music programs, and also taught music production in college. Furthermore, I do piano instruction for all ages, skill levels, and for anyone with a desire to learn.

But I'd like to branch out more into the type of instruction that allowed me to not only become the pianist I am, but to be able to live a normal life that doctors swore I could never have. If I was given this opportunity, so should everyone else.

My rates are relatively low compared to a lot of the major, seasoned instructors in my area. And in a lot of cases, I will actually offer discounts and deals to certain folks (like military, special needs, low income, etc.), because after all, my time doesn't personally cost me anything, but music will have a priceless impact on those who desire it. What does cost money though is things like facilities and materials.

I provide all necessary materials to my students needed to learn, such as reading material, pitch pipes, metronomes, and whatever else may be needed to learn.

So I'm looking for $5000, which breaks down as follows:

  • 250 hours of reduced price lessons (So 500 30-minute lessons)

  • Materials for 500 students

That would allow me to give free lessons to roughly 10 students per week in a year.

And I'd also like to mention that there will be a qualification process in order for a student to receive special funding for lessons. I want to make sure every penny goes to good use.

As I mentioned, the piano basically was the instrument (no pun intended) that allowed me to have two hands that function as good as the average person, and in some circumstances better. Not only am I an award winning pianist, but I can also tie my shoes, properly use my utensils, hold a girl's hand and still be able to open the door for her, type 40 WPM, plus play a slew of other instruments.
On top of the physical implications, music has been shown to increase a students' mathematical and number based cognition, as well as improve logical reasoning, and creative problem solving. There are also studies that show that music in itself may boost IQ and grades. For a developing human, this could make a huge difference later in life. I know it did for me.

Money is tight these days, and I completely understand that not everyone can or will donate. But sometimes just sharing the link for this campaign on your social media page can make a world of difference, and it takes about 5 seconds.

I'm extremely thankful and grateful to everyone for their help!

story:
Short Summary

Hi, I'm Jodie and I'm asking you to make a donation to my campaign, because I am hoping that you will want to be involved with what I am doing here. By donating money to a cause that I feel very strongly about, you will be able to share in this incredible experience with me. 

I am here now in the Philippines with Fund Life, a small but disruptive and bold not-for-profit organisation, whose mission it is to end opportunity apartheid. You can see for yourselves here http://www.fundlife.org/

Together with a team of other volunteers, I am assisting with the organisation of, Sama-Sama Games 2014.  A football event for young people coming from some of the poorest communities across the country, including those affected by typhoon Haiyan. I know not everyone is able to drop everything for a couple of months to be a part of this, and I am fully aware that I am in a very fortunate position to do so. If you want to know more about our event, you can find it here http://www.samagames.org/

I have been on my own personal journey for a while now, trying to make sense of the world we live in. It doesn't escape me for one moment that the opportunities I have available to me, are in part, due to the country in was born in. I've spent a lot of time over the last 15 years traveling to many places around the world and it has definitely helped shape the person I am today. I have been so fortunate to be afforded that opportunity. At times I have been so overwhelmed by the generosity of people far less fortunate than I. Many of these people have  little opportunity to change their circumstances, and yet their strength of spirit is always so humbling to me.

I had been searching for a worthwhile cause to be involved in for a while, so I could finally begin to repay all the kindness I have been shown over the years. I believed that the right opportunity would present itself in time, and I really feel this one has chosen me. I have always been told 'if it's for you, it won't go by you', and it used to annoy me, but now I understand. I've chosen to follow my dreams to the other side of the world and, together with your help, I can hopefully make some of these kids dreams come true too.

What We Need & What You Get

What I'm asking of you, is any donations you are willing and able to make. They will be used to help cover some the costs of my trip. The rest will be given to help host our event. The perks I am offering, I hope, will allow you to share in this journey with me. I want to be able to keep you all updated as our event unfolds, in that way you can all be here with me in spirit.

The Impact

The value of this project resides in the opportunities we want to create for underprivileged young people of the Philippines. We will be encouraging them to make connections with people from varied backgrounds, all across of the Philippines and the world. We want them to use the skills they have learned to continue their education through scholarship programs, and to help foster positive change in their communities. The idea is that they will be inspired to find their passions in life, then given the opportunities they need to pursue them. If they can do this, they will become strong leaders in the future, and eventually inspire others.

Ultimately we want this project to grow arms and legs, so we can focus on longer term goals, that have the potential to not only improve the lives of these kids, but the lives of many others in the future.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you feel you are unable to donate to my project, that's ok, I completely understand. I would, however implore you to share my campaign to everyone you know. That way it may reach as many people as possible.

I understand that my project may not resonate with you, and if that is the case, there are so many worthwhile causes just waiting for you. I found this opportunity on http://www.escapethecity.org/

story:
Twenty years ago, Rwanda was in the darkest place a country can be in. The horrific 1994 genocide was raging over the country and destroying it to the core. Now 20 years later, although Rwanda has fought hard to rise above her past, the rest of the world still knows Rwanda for “the country where the genocide happened.” As everybody says.

 Idebate Rwanda is a group of young people who grew up in a struggling country. We grew up seeing Rwanda put in place a vision 2020 to help her grow economically and put countless of reconciliation programs to restore the trust and sense of community among Rwandans that was lost that day in 1994 when Rwandans killed fellow Rwandans.

 Idebate Rwanda is a group of ambitious children of Rwanda who hope to get the word out there, we are all about letting the world learn about how far Rwanda has come by being the best we can be through debate. Imagine a generation which learnt how to communicate well with each other, a whole population of critical thinkers, people who can disagree with arguments and with no need of weapons to prove a point.

 Idebate Rwanda is a Youth NGO that is working at fostering the power of debate and free speech in a country healing from wounds.

This year marks the 20th genocide anniversary, for that Idebate Rwanda is organizing a tour of North America. This tour will aim at building relationships, connections and will help us groom and raise a new generation of leaders. We will share all the struggles of being a post genocide generation that are most times ignored as well as the honest brutal realities of our generation. Idebate Rwanda brings together students from all walks of life to debate and argue to find solutions to some of the most pressing problems that Rwanda faces, they learn to disagree peacefully as well as gain critical thinking skills and develop communication and networking abilities. We are a lively group of young people trying to make their country a better place for the generations to come. We hope that our children will be born and raised in a society where the genocide is only in the history books and they have less struggles to grow up with. WE need your help.

 Idebate Rwanda is launching this campaign to raise money that will be used for the tour.

·  $12,000: will go for tickets for the team members that are leaving for the USA,

·  $3500: West Coast travel cost,

·  $5000: State to state Travel,

·  $1500: Accommodation,

·  $1000: Food,

·  $2000: Photo Exhibition of Rwanda 20 Years Later

·  $2500 Tickets to Canada

·  $2500 Health Care and health related costs.

We are going to be hosted in schools, universities, interest groups etc… in order to share the story of Rwanda and the way Rwanda has improved in the last 20 years and to share with our counterpart from North America the struggles of a post genocide generation in the hope that they would fight against injustices and wrongs in their communities.

Donate and share the link to friends, families and communities.

was raging over the country and destroying it to the core. Now 20 years later, although
Rwanda has fought hard to rise above her past, the rest of the world still
knows Rwanda for “the country where the genocide happened.” As everybody says.
 Idebate Rwanda is a group of young people who
grew up in a struggling country. We grew up seeing Rwanda put in place a vision
2020 to help her grow economically and put countless of reconciliation programs
to restore the trust and sense of community among Rwandans that was lost that
day in 1994 when Rwandans killed fellow Rwandans.
 Idebate Rwanda is a group of ambitious
children of Rwanda who hope to get the word out there, we are all about letting
the world learn about how far Rwanda has come by being the best we can be
through debate. Imagine a generation which learnt how to communicate well with
each other, a whole population of critical thinkers, people who can disagree
with arguments and with no need of weapons to prove a point.
 Idebate Rwanda is a Youth NGO that is working
at fostering the power of debate and free speech in a country healing from
wounds. 
This year marks the
20th genocide anniversary, for that Idebate Rwanda is organizing a tour of
North America. This tour will aim at building relationships, connections and
will help us groom and raise a new generation of leaders. We will share all the
struggles of being a post genocide generation that are most times ignored as
well as the honest brutal realities of our generation. Idebate Rwanda brings
together students from all walks of life to debate and argue to find solutions
to some of the most pressing problems that Rwanda faces, they learn to disagree
peacefully as well as gain critical thinking skills and develop communication
and networking abilities. We are a lively group of young people trying to make
their country a better place for the generations to come. We hope that our
children will be born and raised in a society where the genocide is only in the
history books and they have less struggles to grow up with. WE need your help.
 Idebate Rwanda is launching this campaign to
raise money that will be used for the tour.
· 
$12,000:
will go for tickets for the team members that are leaving for the USA,
· 
$3500:
West Coast travel cost, 
· 
$5000:
State to state Travel, 
· 
$1500:
Accommodation, 
· 
$1000:
Food, 
· 
$2000:
Photo Exhibition of Rwanda 20 Years Later
· 
$2500
Tickets to Canada
· 
$2500
Health Care and health related costs.
We are going to be
hosted in schools, universities, interest groups etc… in order to share the
story of Rwanda and the way Rwanda has improved in the last 20 years and to
share with our counterpart from North America the struggles of a post genocide
generation in the hope that they would fight against injustices and wrongs in
their communities.Donate and share the link to friends, families and communities.

story:
Why would this guy want to risk his luscious beard?! We are raising funds to donate a unit called a Cuddle Cot to the hospital our son, Amos ♡, was born at on his 1st birthday in his memory. 

Our son was born sleeping on March 10th, 2015.

In short, a Cuddlecot gives families who lose a baby the gift of TIME.

We are willing to do whatever we can to donate this unit in memory of our son.

That's right he is willing to leave it up to you. Will the beard stay or go?

For photographic evidence follow us on Facebook at The Amos Fletcher Fund

story:
Glassmaking in Scotland

Welcome to the Glassmaking in Scotland Fundraising Campaign!

We are a group of graduate and undergraduate art students from Portland, Oregon. We are seeking funds to study glass making at the world renowned North Lands Creative Glass in Lybster, Scotland.

The class runs from July 7th to July 18th and we have already committed to attend, but we are seeking your help to offset travel and material costs. 


What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise $6000 to offset our travel costs. This amount will not cover all of our expenses, but will go a long way toward our airfare. Any amount we raise will be helpful and will allow us to focus on learning once we arrive in Scotland.

In exchange for you your support we are each creating artworks and designs that will be available as perks. Each of these perks are handmade and will be delivered upon the completion of the class.

  • $10 - you will receive our thanks in the form of an original "Thank You" card designed by the group.
  • $25 - For a $25 contribution you can choose between a handmade tote bag designed by OCAC Fiber's BFA Melina Bishop, original recycled glass earrings designed by Laruen Wilson, and a kiln-glass pendant designed by the class' co-instructor Michael Endo.

  • $30 - you will receive a pair of reclaimed wood earrings designed by OCAC BFA student Roberta Olson.
  • $100 - you will receive a pair of metal earrings designed by OCAC MFA candidate Colin Kippen.

  • $150 - One day, private Painting with Glass lesson with Michael Endo. Learn the basic skills needed to create painterly imagery on glass using glass powder and enamels. All materials included. Portland area residents only.
  • $500 - you will receive an original kilncast artwork by co-instructor Emily Nachison.

*Actual artwork will be similar to the image above, but will be created specifically for this fundraising campaign.

  • $2000 - co-instructor Michael Endo will create an original kilnformed artwork based on the landscape around Lybster. 

*Actual artwork will be similar to the image above, but will be made specifically for the this fundraising campaign. Artwork will measure approx. 14 x 18 inches.

KEEP WATCHING - MORE PERKS TO COME!

The Impact

This is an amazing opportunity to study glassmaking in one of the most well-regarded glass centers in the world. In addition to the technical skills we will be learning, the Caithness region of Scotland is home beautiful vistas, stunning geological formations, and anthropological sites that have survived since the Neolithic period. Our explorations in the studio will be fueled by the sites that we visit. 

This is an experience that cannot be replicated anywhere else and will fuel us as we continue to follow our educational and artistic goals.


Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate you taking the time to look over our fundraising campaign and watch our video.

If you are interested in the class please visit: 

https://cms.ocac.edu/Scotland_Field_Studies_in_Glass

For more information. 

Please share!

story:
(Please click on the Updates) tab for the most recent news about our project)

The National Cartoonists Society Foundation and the Kenosha Festival of Cartooning are passionate about supporting children’s charities. As part of festival 2014 we are raising money for Children’s Hospitals of Wisconsin’s Kenosha Clinic and Open Wings – a learning community for children with autism and other learning challenges.

We have many, many desirable and rare items in this auction but, if you don't see anything you wish to bid on - or the prices are out of your budget - and you still wish to support these charities, feel free to make a donation of any amount and click the "no perk" box.

The benefit auction includes original cartoon art, illustrations and collectible ephemera and will happen in two phases:

Online bidding at “buy it now” prices only

  • ·      When: From September 13-25 2014
  • ·      Where: Here on Indiegogo
  • ·      How: Items will be listed as “perks” at their “buy it now” price
  • o   To buy an item select your “perk” and pay via paypal or credit card (you can use major credit cards via paypal)
  • o   Only 20 items can be listed at a time so items will be rotated over the course of the 12 days of the online auction
  • o   Any item unclaimed for more than 3 days will be rotated out – it may come back later but don’t take this for granted
  • o   All unclaimed items will then go to live auction September 27 2014

For details of the live auction click here and scroll down to "live auction".

We have some AMAZING items here and all the money is going to a good cause! We ask that you remember these items are being sold for charity -this is not the sort of auction where you will "get a deal" but you will raise money for two great children's charities in Kenosha.

For a full list of items being offered - with prices - click on the "gallery"tab. If the item you see is not currently a "perk" check back often to see if it is in the current rotation.

story:
What is the Victory Bus Project?

The Victory Bus Project was started 2 years ago by Jalal Sabur. Sabur offers reduced rate rides to families to visit their loved ones in Hudson valley prisons in addition to bringing them a box of healthy fresh food. It means that a parent does not need to decide between going grocery shopping or visiting. They can do both.

The Victory Bus Project has partnered with the Primrose Hill Farm Collective, to provide food for their program.

What is the Primrose Hill Farm Collective?

The Primrose Hill Farm Collective is a passel of like-minded farms partnering with Primrose Hill School, a Waldorf inspired school in the Village of Rhinebeck, NY.

Born in winter 2015, Dan and Tess of Common Hands Farm joined with Primrose Hill School to broaden the scope of their successful CSA into an enterprise called – the Primrose Hill Farm Collective. 

Why is this partnership awesome?

Raising $10,000 is the equivalent of 25 full CSA shares for a family over the full growing season, from June - end of October. A consistent supply of food means that the Victory Bus Project can expand and grow into the community without worrying about where the food for the weekly trips is coming from. 

The Victory Bus Project has been working for 2 years to bring families together. Common Hands Farm, which joined the Primrose Hill Farm Collective in 2015, has been successfully growing biodynamic crops for over 5 years. This is a friendship and relationship built over years that you are catapulting to a new level of impact.

We will be creating a logo to celebrate this partnership over the summer that will go on the teeshirts and totes. Wildflower seed balls made with the small hands of the Primrose Hill School students will brighten up your garden and bring you a smile.

Why this is important?

The majority of the prisoners live hours away from their families, in remove rural areas without access to public transportation. To compound this issue, the communities with the highest rates of incarceration are the same communities considered food deserts.

2.7 million American children have a parent in prison.

Let's feed these kids and help them visit their parents.

We will let the experts explain beyond that... (and thank you Rutgers University for highlighting this).

The uneven geographic distribution of incarceration in poor communities and communities of color means that the effects radiate beyond the individual to the broader community, presenting profound long‐term consequences for family integrity, public health and general quality of life.

 (source: Travis, Jeremy, Solomon, Amy, 2003, Families Left Behind, Urban Institute, Justice Policy Center)

Other Ways You Can Help

Share the word. Share the knowledge. Share the love. Share.

story:
Short Summary

Hey Everyone!  I am getting ready to head back to the School of St. Jude in Arusha, Tanzania this summer, and need a little bit of help to bring some equipment along!  Last year, I helped the P.E. Teachers at St. Jude's develop a curriculum for soccer and handball, this summer they want me to teach them how to teach students baseball.  I have a background in playing, so my curriculum is ready, but I need some equipment to help teach that sport! The School of St. Jude currently has no baseball equipment, and there is no local place in Arusha to purchase it, so I'll bring it all along with me when I head over in June.

L to R: Kim Saville (St. Jude Staff), Grams, Uncle Bruce, Me, Mom!


For those of you who don't know, my family has been working in close partnership with the School of St. Jude since 2005.  My mom, Cindy Skarbek, is on the board of directors for the school and spends about a month each year in Tanzania, and her other time at home developing new programs and partnerships for the school in the USA and beyond. In January 2012, I went to Tanzania with "3 Peaks 3 Weeks", and was able to raise $50,000 for the school and 2 other organizations in East Africa by climbing Mt. Kilimanjaro, Mt. Meru, and Mt. Kenya within a 3 week time span. Last summer, I joined a group of teacher from my high school in Louisville, KY on a teaching journey to St. Jude, where I got to teach a soccer program after school and mentor the P.E. teachers during the school day. My whole trip is being funded by a foundation, so none of this money will be going to offset my expenses, but will be used to help the school and P.E department get the equipment they need!

What We Need

Here is what I'm looking to bring over:

  • 15 durable foam baseball bats
  • 45 dense foam "true fly" baseballs, so the students can learn the game safely and within the space available to them on campus.
  • 10-15 baseball gloves
  • 1 set of rubber bases
  • 2 baseball rule books
  • Any extra funds I raise will go straight to the operating campaign of the school, which serves over 1,800 students and employs hundreds of local Tanzanians 

The Impact 

Why is supporting a school in Arusha, Tanzania impactful?

  • St. Jude's has proven itself as one of the best institutions of learning in Tanzania, ranking 4th out of 355 schools in the Northwest of the country, even competing against private schools! This is a true testament to the vision of the school's leaders, and to the hard work students and teachers put in every day.
  • I have been to the school many times, and can attest to the success of the students attending.  My brother and I sponsor a student now in his 9th year at the school...Vedasto's English is fantastic, he has aspirations to be a doctor, and he helps his younger brothers with their schoolwork when he is home. His family is so grateful he can attend St. Jude's.
  • St. Jude's is educating the future leader's of Tanzania, and ironically, these student's wouldn't be able to afford schooling at all because their families are so poor. St. Jude's is fighting the poverty cycle by providing these children with a quality education.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute financially? That's OK!

  • Spread the word among your friends...maybe someone you know has a passion for education, Africa, or just knows me and likes me! :)
  • Please ask me about the school when you see me! I've got so many stories I can share about St. Jude's...one of my favorite places on earth!

Thanks for the support! If you need any more information or have any questions, feel free to ask.

With Sincere Gratitude,

Katherine

story:
Hello everyone! I am Tamara Khlghatyan from the small city of Gyumri , which is located In Armenia.  I am 24 years old and I currently study in a small university, majoring in translation studies. I  graduated from my school in 2009 and was immediately accepted to study in the European Academy. In 2009 I  was one of  11 students from all over Armenia who were chosen to study in the United States as a university  exchange student. Over the last two years I have been rigorously combining my work and studies in Armenia and Georgia.  My wish now is to finally my BA degree and start my MA as photojournalist.  I will stay dedicated to my studies and give everything of myself, so that I can manage to succeed. Upon returning to Armenia  form the US with 3.58GPA, I finished my first junior semester and had to drop out of my university due to  financial problems. Unfortunately, I am unable to receive any government assistance due to negligence on their part. After taking a 3 year break, I have found scholarship that provides financial support for students to studying MA. To pursue studying MA degree, I first have to finish my BA degree. I went back to university and replaced my previous university with a more reasonable /less expensive one.  Unfortunately my high grades and social activism were not much helpful for earning a  scholarship due to the low number of students  in my university.  I believe in hustle and hard work more than I believe in luck, but even that is sometimes not enough for a young woman who was born in a small city that is still under construction after the disastrous earthquake in 1988. My parents are unable to contribute much towards my tuition, so the majority of my tuition will have to come from elsewhere.

I'm raising money to help cover the costs of attendance ($500) at my university.

For me education is the most valuable tool we have for changing and inspiring youth. I'm in love with the work I do, and I want to be able to do it every single day. Your contribution means I can continue moving towards. I would be forever grateful for any donation- every bit counts.

With so many worthy causes I know it is difficult to decide which ones to support. I can only say your sponsorship would provide a hard working, socially conscientious Armenian  student the opportunity to reach her dreams.

If you are unable to donate, please consider  sharing this on social media and with anyone you know who may be willing to donate.

story:
What is the TSC?

The Transfer Service Community (TSC) is a group of UC Berkeley and community college students that assist community college students in transferring to any four-year university, getting involved in public service, and connecting to resources. Our mission is to increase support for prospective transfer students in accomplishing their goals. We believe in a holistic approach, and we meet students where they're at. A significant portion of community college students are homeless or food insecure. We think these basic needs must be addressed to achieve student success. We also believe student involvement is crucial in the college experience and essential to retention and feeling supported.

The TSC has served thousands of students around the San Francisco Bay Area and has provided over 40 transfer, scholarship, leadership, and service events since Spring 2010 (Please see our list of workshops and events below).  We also meet with students one-on-one to share our personal experiences with community college and transferring, connect them to volunteer opportunities, as well as share resources as basic as food and housing. As students, we understand what students need, and we're able to support them in an empathetic, way that empowers them and encourages independence. 

Our AMAZING video was created by Ajakari Mark Angelo of Anonymity Films. Check out his website! http://www.anonymityfilms.com/

(Our most recent UC Berkeley Shadow Day with over 100 attendees from 20 different community colleges) 

How can you help? 

We need $50,000 for three main categories: staffing, supplies, and sustainability. 

Staffing: We currently have 10 Peer Advisors and Transfer Liaisons in our program, and we want to make sure that they receive scholarships for the work that they do! They donate 10 hours/week of their time to make our program happen, AND they're all full time students. 

Supplies: We're incredibly frugal and have gotten many of our supplies donated, however we still need money for marketing supplies (flyers, posters, business cards, t-shirts, and banners), office supplies (pens, tape, markers, staplers, etc.), and food supplies for our workshops and events.  

Sustainability: In order to take the next step in our program, we need to hire a full time staff person to create a sustainable source of funding for our program. 

If we don't reach our goal, we'll use the money that we make to fund a part time position and continue paying for our supplies. 

Perks: 

All donations are tax deductible. In exchange for your generous donation, you can get a Facebook shout-out, a handwritten letter, or a homemade video from grateful students who have been assisted by our program. You can also be entered to win one of our donated gift certificates. There's also an opportunity to receive an invitation to meet with our amazing team! 

                                        

(A team building game at our 2012 Leadership and Service Retreat) 

Can't Donate? Here are other ways you can help: 

  • Share our campaign with your social network (call a friend, send an e-mail, or use Indiegogo's great "share" tools)! Spreading the word helps us tremendously! 
  • Volunteer with our program to assist with events and workshops. 
  • Donate food, office supplies, or other resources. 
  • Donate perks for us to give away. 
  • Let us know if we can add your program or organization to our list of supporters!
     
(Our 2011-2012 Team)                                  (Our 2012-2013 Team) 

                                         (Our 2013-2014 Team)

Awards and Funding : 

  • The Big Ideas Award: Improving Student Life (2011) and Scaling Up (2013) Categories
  • The Chancellor's Community Partnership Fund (2011 & 2013)
  • The Associated Students of the University of California, Berkeley
  • The Student Initiated Community Projects Grant

                           

                (The poster presentation for the 2013 Big Ideas Awards at UC Berkeley)

Brief History:

Our program began as a response to the education budget cuts that reduced and eliminated resources, staff, and faculty. Community Colleges were hit the hardest by these cuts compared to the K-12, Cal State, and University of California systems.  We were able to fund our program through two grants that we won and support from the UC Berkeley Public Service Center. Over the first two years, we built stronger relationships with programs and people at local community colleges and UC Berkeley and created workshops and events. In Spring 2013 we won two more grants to expand our services to Laney College and partner with Berkeley High School to provide a Leadership and Service Retreat.  

                 

(Our creator, Caleb Westberg, at the Spring 2012 Shadow Day )

The Impact

Student testimonials:

The Transfer Service Community(TSC) is dedicated to helping community college students transfer. Their commitment to building an informational bridge between the community colleges and four-year universities significantly contributed to my successful transfer to the UC Berkeley Haas School of Business from Berkeley City College. I have attended and benefited from some of the workshops and events that contained extremely valuable information about resources and programs available to prospective transfer students. These included the Personal Statement and Application Workshop, Shadow Day at UC Berkeley, Resume and Interview Workshop, Scholarships Workshop, Transfer Student Panel, and the "Next Steps" for UC Berkeley Admitted Transfer Students Workshop. I am mostly grateful for the one-on-one advising sessions the TSC has offered me. My Transfer Liaison made me believe that transferring to Haas was not just a dream but reality. She guided me every step from giving me critical feedback on my personal statements to giving me advice about my classes and professors at UC Berkeley.  She always made time to fit me in her busy schedule, even if this meant early Sunday mornings or late evenings, and she cleared my uncertainties about the transferring process. Finally, she defiantly reached beyond herself in assisting others and has inspired me to get involved in my community and help other prospective transfer students.
-Rumyana (Business Major/Transfer student at UC Berkeley)

The Peer Advisors are one of the greatest assets a transfer student can utilize while completing the transfer process. Their competent and caring approach in guiding students is truly marvel. Using the Peer Advisors several times myself, I strongly recommend them to any student who wants to succeed while attending community college and beyond. 
-Michael (Political Science Major/Transfer student at UC Berkeley)
When I was the traditional age of going to university, there were no resources like The Transfer Service Community ("TSC"). Their mission (from my perspective) is to help prospective transfer students in transferring to higher education without getting the runaround. The founders of the TSC encountered frustration when they were seeking information on how to transfer to higher education. The TSC came into existence at about the same time when I contemplated transferring to UC Berkeley to pursue a BA in film and media studies. I participated in TSC's first Shadow Day in Spring 2010 at UC Berkeley. I learned what UC Berkeley is all about, what resources are available to transfer students, and what it means to be a UC Berkeley student. My favorite part of the program was the student panel. Hearing about their transfer stories gave me a lot of hope in transferring to UC Berkeley. And here I am in 2014, a UC Berkeley transfer student! TSC's mission is to encourage and help community college students transfer to much higher educational institutions in order to think more critically and to improve their quality of life. They provide assurance, assistance, and encouragement in the process of transferring such as guiding the prospective candidate in writing personal statements, providing information on scholarships and how to apply for them, organizing activities such as Shadow Day, holding seminars such as student panels, and much more. The Transfer Service Community needs our assistance in any way, shape, and/or form to keep their program going so they can continue providing assistance to transfer students in their dream pursuing higher education. Please give what you can to help them. Thank you. Fiat Lux! Go Bears!
-Cristina (UC Berkeley Film and Media Studies major)

(One of our past Transfer Liaisons, Anakaren Alcocer, giving a transfer workshop at Laney College)

Program Positions: 

Peer Advisors: Community college students that volunteer their time to meet with students one-on-one and connect them to on campus/off campus resources and opportunities. 
Transfer Liaisons: UC Berkeley students, who successfully transferred from community college that plan the workshops and events and share their transfer experience with students through one-on-one advising. 

Program Coordinator: responsible for overseeing the direction of the program and the marketing campaigns, training the participants, and raising funding through grant writing, fundraising, and sponsorship. 

                          

(One of our original Peer Advisors, Cinthia Simon, talking with her friends. They all assisted with the Berkeley High School Leadership & Service Retreat)


Past Workshops and Events include:

  • Basics of Transferring Workshop: learn everything from how to pick a major to the basic steps of applying to any four-year university. 
  • UC Application and Personal Statement Workshop: hear a UC Berkeley admissions officer cover tips and tricks on the UC application, especially the personal statement section.
  • Shadow Day: an opportunity for community college students to visit the UC Berkeley campus, connect to resources and programs, and become acquainted with the campus culture.
  • Veteran Transfer Resources: how to take advantage of your GI benefits and convey your Veteran experience in your personal statements 
  • Student-Parent Resources: connecting student-parents to resources that they can access 
  • Leadership and Service Retreat: an annual retreat for student leaders to learn about their leadership styles and how to work with others, as well as explore what it means to serve their communities.
  • Scholarship Workshop: Finding and Applying for Scholarships and other options to pay for college
  • Resume and Interview Workshop: covering the various styles, types, trends, sections, and content of resumes, as well as interview tips  
  • Next Steps after acceptance to UC Berkeley: everything from acronyms and lingo to ways to make the most of your time at Cal
  • Majors Panel: a panel on different majors that students can study
  • Bay Area School Panel: students from schools around the Bay Area share their experiences. 
  • Meet & Greet: an opportunity for students to meet our team
  • Service Fair: an opportunity for community organizations to offer volunteer positions and internships. 

(On the left: A workshop flyer created by past Transfer Liaison, Connor Murphy. On the right: part of a brilliant campaign, created by the Assistant Program Coordinator, Sarah Dadouch.) 

Formal Partners:

  • The UC Berkeley Public Service Center (formerly Cal Corps)
  • The Berkeley High School Leadership Program
  • The Transfer Re-Entry Student Parent Center

Supporters:

  • The BCC and Laney Transfer Centers
  • The BCC and Laney EOPS Programs
  • Laney's APASS Program
  • Trio at Laney
  • BCC and Laney Counselors and Professors
  • Matthew Freeman: Political Science Department Head and co-founder for the Institute for Civic and Community Engagement
  • BCC Clubs
  • Peralta Student Trustees: Brian Cervantes, Esteem Brumfield, Sharon Clegg, Rich Copenhagen
  • The Associated Students of Laney College, Berkeley City College, and College of Alameda
  • Starting Point Mentorship Program
  • The UC Berkeley Undergraduate Admissions Office
  • The UC Berkeley Career Center
  • The UC Berkeley Scholarship Office

                                  

(Two of our past Peer Advisors, Prema Baba and Alphonse Owirka, at our 2013 Service Fair. Both are now students at UC San Diego)

Risks & Challenges

One of the hurtles we have faced is the lack of institutional support. We believe that having a full time position to secure future funding and institution support will enable us to be sustainable.
story_txt:
What is the TSC?
The Transfer Service Community (TSC) is a group of UC Berkeley and community college students that assist community college students in transferring to any four-year university, getting involved in public service, and connecting to resources. Our mission is to increase support for prospective transfer students in accomplishing their goals. We believe in a holistic approach, and we meet students where they're at. A significant portion of community college students are homeless or food insecure. We think these basic needs must be addressed to achieve student success. We also believe student involvement is crucial in the college experience and essential to retention and feeling supported.


The TSC has served thousands of students around the San Francisco Bay Area and has provided over 40 transfer, scholarship, leadership, and service events since Spring 2010 (Please see our list of workshops and events below).  We also meet with students one-on-one to share our personal experiences with community college and transferring, connect them to volunteer opportunities, as well as share resources as basic as food and housing. story:
The beginning.

It is hard to argue against the need of education in developing countries.  In the Dominican Republic, a new system is being implemented that changes the school day from 5 hours a day to 8 hours to allow children to be taken care of while their parents are at work.  This is a great step for the country.  The public schools are free to all children, but for children to be eligible for school, they must have uniforms, supplies, and two pair of shoes.  This totals about $100.00 per child.  If the family can't afford this, their child is not allowed into the system. 

The middle.

My goal is to raise money to help outfit children to give them the opportunity that so many of us take for granted,  Education is the key to improving quality of life and changing the world.  
I recently took a trip to the DR and met a man named Lee.  He runs a small beach burger bar business and contributes to the community as much as he can. He collects money from his profits, and donors and takes local kids shopping to prepare them for school.

    The end.

    Whatever money is collected will be donated to Lee's fund to help children get outfitted for the upcoming school year.  With the new school hours and how that can positively impact a family with working parents, it is more important than ever to encourage enrollment, This could be the stepping stone that families need to get a better job, to provide more for their family, knowing that their children are not only taken care of while they are away, but in a future building environment

    The bibliography.

    http://www.therealdr.com/dominican-republic-life/dominican-republic-education.html

    http://www.dw.de/dominican-republic-revamps-failing-education-system/a-17625149
    https://www.facebook.com/biglees.beachbar

story:
The Program -- 40 Years of Immersion!

Montgomery County Public Schools has the distinction of housing the oldest French Immersion program in the nation.  Founded in 1974, the program has been a model for many other state programs, most recently the state of Utah.  French Immersion serves over 700 students in grades K-8 in Montgomery County, many of whom will then be able to move onto AP French or the International Baccalaureate program.  All Montgomery County students have equal access to French Immersion as enrollment is determined by lottery. 

French Immersion is offered at the following schools: Maryvale Elementary School, Sligo Creek Elementary School, Gaithersburg Middle School, and Silver Spring International Middle School.

What We Need To Celebrate

We are celebrating our 40 years of success on March 28, 2015 at 2:00 p.m. in Northwood High School’s auditorium.

  • Your donation will enable us to serve the approximately 1,000 guests we are expecting to celebrate with us on March 28.
  • Your generous donation will be acknowledged in our event program and on the Facebook page and listserv for our many families. 
  • Your listing in the event program will demonstrate your community spirit and your support of foreign language education.

Bring Together Current Students and Alumni

We are looking forward to hosting current and former students and teachers.  The celebration will feature:

  • Class presentations
  • Speakers
  • A video about immersion
  • Photo displays
  • Refreshments

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Background

The McCallum High School Band is one of the preeminent high school bands in the country.  The band just completed another successful marching season and is entering into a new semester full of concert performances, contests and auditions.  Under the expert direction of Carol Nelson, Matt Ehlers and Jeff Rudy, the student musicians continue a tradition of musical excellence at McCallum. To do so, they need our financial support to cover various instructional, travel and equipment expenses.   

Pledge to support Mike's walk!

Band parent Mike Pauwels has taken up the challenge to walk from McCallum HS in Austin to the Texas Music Educators Association convention in San Antonio.  Several members of the MAC Band are to perform at this convention.  Mike will start his walk on February 8th and plans to arrive at the convention in San Antonio on Feb 12th. His route will cover approximately 95 miles! 

  • Support the MAC band by pledging to Mike's effort at any level.  No contribution is too small (or too large!).
  • Donations go to the MAC Band Booster Association, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, and as such are tax deductible.
  • Our initial goal was to raise at least $1000 for the band, but WE HAVE AN UPDATED GOAL OF $2256 TO FUND THE PURCHASE OF A NEW DRUM MAJOR PODIUM as our current podium is unsafe.
  • Please forward this to family and friends who might like to support the band by donating to Mike's walk. You can use the Indiegogo share tools to make this easy.
Mike has been blogging about his motivations for taking on this challenge and his preparations for successfully completing the journey.   You can find his blog posts at https://aboutwalking.wordpress.com/

Thank you for your support of the MAC band!  And thank you Mike Pauwels!

*** You will see on the following page that donations are going to "Parent Booster USA".  This is indeed the MAC Band Booster Association's account.  It was set up through Parent Booster USA.

story:
Last year, supporters like you helped us at Scottie's Place to bring the Leadership Education & Empowerment Program (LEEP) to the Dukwi refugee camp in Botswana. We can say with confidence and sincere pride that LEEP 2014 was a major success! We'll get into the achievements below, but here's what one mother said just a couple months ago:

"I'm so happy because LEEP has helped my daughter to open up, to express herself. Now she can represent other students or the school. I pray that LEEP can continue next year." - LEEP Parent

This appreciation and desire to see LEEP sustained was echoed time and again by parents, teachers, and students. We are thrilled to continue LEEP in the Dukwi camp in 2015, but we can't do it alone and hope that you'll join us. Check out the short Thank You video, read through our plans for next year, and please consider supporting LEEP and the Dukwi camp community. 

So, What is LEEP again?

For those of you who are new to LEEP, or if you just need a refresher, LEEP is a global initiative of Scottie's Place, a nonprofit organization based in the US that seeks to assist children affected by poverty and conflict. LEEP is predominately an after-school program that provides academic enrichment and leadership development for all grade 7 students living in the Dukwi refugee camp. With ongoing training and professional support, 12 qualified staff members from the refugee community offer students one-on-one tutoring and mentorship, as well as lead various games and activities designed to deepen students' personal growth and strengthen their leadership skills. As a result of their participation in LEEP, students enhance their self-esteem, confidence, self-awareness and commitment to learning. This growth, situated within an environment that emphasizes community well-being, conflict resolution, and service to others, translates to healthier, stronger relationships at home and sparks the beginning of greater positive social change. 

How was LEEP 2014?

The impact of LEEP in 2014 was both deeper and wider than we had ever anticipated. We knew that offering a child one-on-one attention and providing assistance to their specific needs would make a big difference in their lives. This individualized approach is the essence of all our organization's programs. But personal change usually takes time and recognition of such growth isn't always so widespread. As you'll see from the points below, LEEP students made great progress both academically and in their personal development. Teachers, parents, siblings, community members, and even other local schools noticed and praised the students and staff for their achievements. It was the personal commitment of each student and staff member to the transformation of themselves and their community that made LEEP so successful.

  • In July 2014, 67% of students passed their end-of-term 2 exams. Of these same students, only 44% passed their end-of-February exams, just prior to LEEP's official launch.
  • LEEP students worked exceptionally hard throughout the year to develop their self-esteem and confidence. Collectively, students reported that they possessed low self-esteem prior to LEEP, but progressed to a normal self-esteem score according to Rosenberg’s Self-Esteem Scale. 95% of students reported that their confidence strengthened as a result of LEEP. 
  • In June 2014, LEEP staff designed and facilitated a two-day training on the core components of LEEP for 25 volunteers from the village that hosts the refugee camp. Upon learning of the successes of LEEP in the camp primary school, the host community’s Tachibona Primary School headmistress approached LEEP staff requesting assistance in implementing their own after-school tutoring program. The community-led program was aimed at supporting the national grade 7 students as they prepare for the end-of-year exam. 
  • In September 2014, four students and two staff members visited Maru-a-Pula (MaP) Secondary School in Gaborone. MaP, Botswana’s leading secondary school, hosted students and staff on campus for nearly one week and supported the LEEP students as they attended classes, received one-on-one tutoring, participated in team building activities, and experienced the MaP’s service-focused culture.

“Since LEEP started I changed myself. I started to have respect always and everywhere I go. I change myself because of LEEP. LEEP helped me to be a better leader for my community because LEEP taught me to have respect for big people, to have respect everywhere you go!!!” - LEEP Student



What will LEEP look like in 2015?

The vast majority of the program will be exactly the same. We will continue to provide LEEP to all grade 7 students and will maintain an individualized approach. We will expand our school holiday activities to include the LEEP students from this year who have moved on to junior secondary school. These former LEEP students will be given the opportunity to learn how to tutor younger students, expanding the reach of LEEP and strengthening community empowerment. By bringing on more staff next year, we will commit to identifying additional opportunities to serve both the refugee community and the local host community. In all, we are keeping what worked so well and striving toward strengthening relationships between members of the refugee community and the relationship between the camp and the village that hosts it. 

“Before LEEP started, I used to fail in school and I used to be very stubborn toward my parents. But now I have improved my self-confidence, self-esteem and I now have great respect for my parents and elders.” - LEEP Student


How Can I Help?

Most urgently, we need to raise $10,000 to ensure that LEEP 2015 can happen. Because of our partnership with the UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR), we're able to keep program costs very low. Every dollar donated to LEEP goes to LEEP and helps to make sure that students have the supplies they need to be successful, staff are fairly compensated, community service projects can be realized, and our impact can be properly measured. 

In addition to giving, we also ask our supporters to share this site with their friends, families, and other networks. We also ask you to follow us on Facebook so that you can stay up-to-speed with happenings from Dukwi and even communicate directly with LEEP staff. We encourage our supporters to stay engaged and therefore hope that you will consider yourself a part of the LEEP family. 

Thank You!

We truly hope that you're as excited about LEEP 2015 as we are. The Dukwi camp community made it clear that they deeply appreciate LEEP and want the program to continue next year. Together, let's make sure we honor their request. 
If you have any questions about LEEP, the Dukwi refugee camp, or would like to know of other ways you can support the program, please don't hesitate to email Matt Vincent who is leading the program in Dukwi. 


To learn more about LEEP or Scottie's Place, please visit our website!

story:
A call for Help!!!!

Hello everyone. I am Wilson Magaya, a father of 3 and 1 on the way. I am reaching out to you to raise $9,000 to help me send books of all forms and sizes to Zimbabwe for children in desperate need of reading/learning materials. I am reaching out to you so that together we can send a message of hope.

I have been inspired by the efforts of young women from across the developing world, whose life stories and exceptional efforts and achievements I have had the privilege to share. In my professional career, I have met some amazing people, both face-to-face and on paper. Their collective experiences have moved me to do something for my own people. I have come to the realization that The future of my country rests in the children and the resilience of the women who are on the front-line of life, raising these children with very little to work with.

As a first step I then send out a request through my home church, Marondera United Methodist Church, in Zimbabwe, asking how I could be of service to them. The amazing responses were simple and to the point. “Please send BOOKS” With this I approached my church, the Rockville United Methodist Church and a book project that send books all over the world to help me put together a care package.

  1. The Rockville United Methodist church took up the challenge and made the effort a mission to Zimbabwe. Thus far we have collected over 2000 books to fill a pallet and we are now looking forward to sending out our 1st shipment.
  2. A package of over 30,000 books will be packed and shipped to Marondera by a benevolent organization here in the USA. They will take care of shipping costs to nearest sea port (port of Beira) and we have to raise the money needed to ship the books from Beira port to Marondera.
  3. This is the first of an on-going effort to send books in any form to Zimbabwe we are starting an open call to raise money to build an organization in Zimbabwe that enables our noble mission to continue.

Why am I reaching out to you?

I am reaching out to you because I know you and believe that you will help me raise USD9,000 to do the following;

  • Ship a pallet with 2000 books to Zimbabwe from Rockville United Methodist Church in Maryland to Marondera in Zimbabwe.
  • Fund the last-mile overland shipping of a 40 ft container with over 30,000 books from Beira port to Marondera, and finally
  • I am asking you to help the Zimbabwe team which is mainly composed of church going retirees to register a trust to run a Center for Women and Children that will have high speed internet and so give access to over 40,000 free book titles online. We foresee a future where a computer tablet per-child will reduce scarcity of books and learning materials.

The Impact

In this campaign we are reaching out to over 20 schools with a total enrollment of over 20,000 school children. Our libraries have a reach of over 100,000 children. With the center in operation we will be able to reach any child anywhere in Zimbabwe through an online library.

Our Challenge

The past 10 years have seen the marginalization of Zimbabwe and its people as an integral part of the global village by the International community resulting in people loosing hope. In the worst case children have no classrooms and teachers no proper houses. The greatest risk is that the once highly motivated and eager to learn children of my country have lost hope in the system and question the value of learning, reading if it cannot help one better their lives. Our greatest challenge is entwined in our gift. Lets work together to give hope and show women and children of Zimbabwe that the world cares.


Do something......

Make noise and let our voice be heard share our message so that we can raise enough money to send books to Zimbabwe and start to build a beacon of hope for all.

Use the share tools herein to share this message to all your friends and colleagues. To make a contribution please click on the contribute button and fill in the amount you wish to contribute and submit.
