story:
Like us on Facebook here and follow us on Twitter @Internnection.

When I was back in high school, I was a “science research student.” This means that I invested three years of high school, and two valuable summers, seriously researching a topic of my choice at a laboratory. During my senior year of high school, I had completed a professional research paper, and I presented the results of my experiment to the scientific community at a series of conferences and science competitions. This was easily the most valuable experience of my high school career, and helped me prepare to become a college student in a STEM field.

-Chris Murphy, Co-Founder

P.S.- Internnection is a finalist for the Duke Start-Up Challenge. If we raise at least $5,000 we qualify for their summer start-up accelerator program!!


What is Internnection?

  Internnection is a web-based software solution designed to link up students with potential mentors who are willing to take on high school students. By putting both students and researchers on the same network, we’re eliminating the inequitable need for a pre-existing research program with connections to the research world in a high school.  As such, a student from the inner city has access to the similar opportunities as a student from a specialty school for math and science. 

  Internnection also provides tools for research teachers to help manage and organize their research students if a high school has a science research program. This will help high schools around the country that do not have science research programs begin successful ones with relative ease, thus greatly increasing the amount of students becoming interested in the STEM fields. By increasing access to science research opportunities, Internnection invests in our world’s future in STEM advancement.

Check out our site

Catalyzing Research Opportunities Today, For the Scientists of Tomorrow



Meet the Internnection Team

Here’s a quick introduction to our founding team at Internnection (complete with throwback pictures from our high school research competition days).


Chris Murphy

  Chris is currently a junior at Duke University where he is studying Biomedical Engineering with minors in Computer Science and Computational Biology and Bioinformatics. In high school, he researched in the Chemistry Department of Hofstra University in Uniondale, New York. 



Zack Kronstat

  Zack is a junior at Swarthmore College where he is an Honors Special Major in Educational Studies and Sociology and Anthropology. Zack has worked closely with educational organizations such as Harlem RBI in New York, New York; a non-profit that uses the power of teams to give inner-city youth the chance to "Play, Learn and Grow". In high school, he was a researcher in the Microbiology Department at NYU School of Medicine. 



Jeffrey Caso

  Jeff is a junior at the Georgetown University School of Foreign Service studying Science, Technology, and International Affairs with a concentration in Security Studies. Since a young age, he has been obsessed with all things related to information technology. Now, he focuses the bulk of my studies on big data and the future of cyber-warfare. Jeff is also the Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Georgetown International Relations Club.



The Internnection Solution

  Internnection provides students, teachers, and researchers with the tools to make the entire process of science research more organized and efficient. Here’s a small illustration to provide you with an idea of how Internnection help. A more detailed look at the functionality of the site can be found at the bottom of our summary!


Your Impact and Perks!

  By donating to our campaign, you are investing in the future of STEM research and achievement. The high school students who are gaining research lab experience today are the scientists, doctors, and engineers of tomorrow who may revolutionize the way we live!

  Helping us out will also help all demographics gain access to STEM opportunities, since Internnection is committed to helping students of all backgrounds gain research experience.

With your donation you can get cool perks like limited edition t-shirts and even a chance to get your name forever engraved on our website here! Donate to our campaign today and become a founder!

Don’t forget to follow us on Twitter, @Internnection, and share our campaign with friends!


Funding Allocation

  We are looking to raise at least $10,000 through this Indiegogo campaign. The reasons for this need are illustrated below.


Initial Front End Development: Between the three of us, we have enough expertise with front end programming to manage and occasionally update our user interface, but do not have enough expertise or time to develop the full-scale professional grade user experience that we envision for Internnection. Therefore, we have contracted a front-end designer to do this for us.

Back End Development: Internnection will provide an extremely helpful software solution for science research, which means we will require help with its development. We need funds to hire a contractual back-end programmer to help us build Internnection.

Marketing/Outreach: While the main goal of this campaign is to raise funds for building the site, we also need a small amount of money to start marketing Internnection. Our main marketing tactic (which we are very confident in) is to sponsor Intel ISEF events. ISEF stands for Intel International Science and Engineering Fair. Intel sponsors science and engineering fairs annually throughout the country, all of which are qualifiers for the final, prestigious, Intel ISEF Finals event in May. Internnection would be able to sponsor these events, allowing us to travel to these events and speak to hundreds of students and high school teachers, as well as reaching out to the professional science researchers who attend as judges.

Even if we don’t reach our goal, the money we do raise can still help us begin to develop our website and reach out to high schools and research institutions.


More Website Details

Student Platform

  When a student logs on, they are brought to their student homepage. This includes a list of current assignments organized by teacher assignments and laboratory mentor assignments (for when they are conducting their research), a calendar highlighting deadlines for research competitions or important research tasks. The student can then select the assignment or calendar tabs to view these two components in more detail. Furthermore, the student can select the messenger tab to communicate with their mentor or teacher, or even share important documents with them. Lastly, the Search tab brings the student to the internship search application. This will begin with them on a page containing a search engine for finding relevant research opportunities. This search engine will allow them to specify search parameters like research keywords, time required for the internship, and location. Once students find internship opportunities they are interested in, they can apply to work for these mentors by “internnecting” with them. This action will instantly send the students resume, coursework, cover letter, and any other required material to the researcher to be organized in their applicant list.

Teacher Organization Platform

  When a teacher logs on, they will be brought to their homepage, which will consist of a calendar of important deadlines, an interface through which they can post an announcement for certain students to see, and tabs for each of their classes or groups. They will also have access to a master list of all of their research students. Using this master list of students, they can create new groups of students, whether this is for reorganizing students into classes for a new school year, or grouping together students that are attending the same research competition. This will help teachers send out assignments or announcements to the right students at the right times. Teachers can navigate through the groups to message an entire group, or find a specific student in order to contact them or exchange documents, like research paper edits or competition application essays.

Researcher Organization Platform

  The research platform will be similar to the teach platform. The researcher, after logging in, will view a homepage that contains a calendar that highlights important deadlines for their lab. They will also have an interface through which to send out announcements to their lab interns. If the researcher has multiple labs, they can group interns together by lab. These separate labs will then appear as tabs on the researcher’s homepage. They will also have access to a master list of all students, through which they can either select a student to message or exchange documents with, or use to create new groups (i.e. those working on the same project, those working in the same lab).

  The other portion of the research platform takes care of the intern selection process. Researchers can click on the profile tab to view their profile, which interested students can view to learn more about their research. They can edit this profile at any time. Furthermore, they can select the Applicants tab to view an organized list of students who have applied to work in their research lab. This will provide the researcher with an easy to use system through which to sort through their possible interns.  To save time for the researcher if he/she so chooses, they can allow approved lab members (i.e. graduate student, secretary) to have login access to their Internnection account to help manage the intern applicant process.

Guest User Access

  We understand that even if many researchers utilize the lab organization platform we offer free to research institutions, science researchers may still have interns that do not use Internnection. Since we still want the researchers to be able to organize their lab interns to the fullest extent, researchers will be able to make guest user accounts for student interns to use. These temporary accounts will enable the interns to log in and utilize the mentor communication functionality of the student platform in order for their mentor to be able to use their lab organization tools. These guest accounts will not allow students to communicate with teachers, search for other research opportunities, or have access to any research competition organization/planning tools/guides.

story:
Friends and family,

In the wake of typhoon Yolanda, I have decided to go to Bantayan island to help in the rebuilding of the local elementary school.

I am looking for any contribution to help get me there. All money will go towards  expenses and build materials.

I hope you understand that it is not in my nature to ask for personal charity. I believe that this is an important trip for a significant cause. 

If you wish to help but are unable to contribute monetarily, please share this friends family and coworkers.

As a thank you, every contributor will receive a personal photographic gift from me. 

Thanks so much for taking the time to read this. I hope to spread all the love, strength and positivity that you as my friends and family have bestowed upon me.

Shannon

story:
What Is This Anyway?

Does KhodeUp sound far-fetched? Let me change your mind.

My half-brother and five cousins grew up in an orphanage outside Phnom Penh. The youngest two are still there. Except for Rith, who works on a farm, the older kids all work in the ‘hospitality’ industry where they feel lucky to earn $80/month.

I’ve traveled to visit them five times, spending a total of 23 weeks in Cambodia. My brother and I have always loved hanging out at the orphanage. The kids are just like us -- funny, smart, and curious about the world. When I was there last November I talked to Srey Art, a girl who won the education lottery. She's coming to the US for college. I asked what she wants to study, then I practically punched the wall when I heard her answer. She really really wants to study computers, but she has no experience. So she'll study business instead.

!@#$%*!#!!!

To understand why that answer so offends me, you've got to know that I’m a tech addict. I started simple coding in kindergarten, moving on to website design when I was 11. Last summer I spent eight weeks at Twitter with Girls Who Code, and I’ll study computer science when I go to college next year. Until the immersion program at Twitter, I was completely self-taught. Like most coders, all I needed to get started was a computer and an Internet connection.

Within a couple hours of the conversation with Srey Art, I started researching Internet/computer science opportunities in Phnom Penh. Two things stood out: the exponential growth of smart phones in Cambodia, and the dearth of websites designed by and for Khmer users. The conclusion: huge opportunity for Khmer web developers.

Entering this field has a low bar in terms of assets and infrastructure: a laptop, a good Internet connection, and a basic introduction to coding. These are all things that we can provide through KhodeUp.The idea gains real urgency when you compare what my cousins make waiting on tables ($80/month) to the going rate for building a website in Phnom Penh ($200/site).

Will all KhodeUp students become web developers? Probably not. But a few will, and the rest will get language practice and tech skills that will be huge assets in other fields. We've talked with a lot of people about this class, and I'm confident the model is solid. If KhodeUp is successful this summer we can recruit more instructors and scale it.

This class is going to change lives. Who wouldn’t want to be a part of that? Help me get these teens started. I’ll keep in touch with you so you can see what they accomplish. They can’t wait. Neither can I.

What We Need & What You Get

The 2014 pilot program is a four-week immersion class for 20-30 older teens at Future Light Orphanage outside of Phnom Penh. Students will learn HTML, CSS, and the basics of JavaScript and design. Our $15,000 goal will cover equipment, software, an Internet upgrade, web hosting, airfare, and room and board.

If  tax-deductible contributions outpace our expenses, we can provide  incentives for the kids to start their own tech businesses or to teach others, as well as a year-round part-time instructor to help continue the learning.

We are affiliated with eGlobal Family and FLOW Orphanage. Through the emotional and financial support of eGlobal Family foster parents, sponsored children are afforded the opportunity to develop into more confident and self-reliant individuals. For 10 years the organization has supported hundreds of children at Future Light Orphanage in Cambodia and has recently formed new partnerships with orphanages throughout Southeast Asia. These are not religiously affiliated organizations.

Ah!  Here's the fun stuff you can get with a tax-deductible contribution!  For just $25 you can get some snazzy stickers. I know I love stickers.  A mere $100 gets you a personal thank you note from a KhodeUp student.  For $250 you get a personal invite to participate in Demo Day at the end of the program, where you'll be able to watch our students present their final projects via Internet. (Pray to the Wifi Gods and don't worry, if you can't make it we will record the whole event and post it on our Vimeo later!) Those in the MoonMoon category at $1,000 can Skype with some of our students about their projects.

Kramas, traditional Khmer scarves, are  a fun perk for the Ermagherd ($500) and MoonMoon ($1,000) donor levels. These uniquely Cambodian scarves can adorn your neck, wrap around your waist, keep out the sun, and hoist a live chicken.

FAQ!

What's up with the .kh? People ask this a lot. Kh is Cambodia's web-extension. More importantly, "kh" is my way of signifying Khmer, which means Cambodian.  So that "kh" means this program belongs to Khmer teens. KhodeUp will give them the skills, gear, and continuing troubleshooting they need to start building websites for Khmer clients. 

What the heck is up with your donor level names?  Okay I'm an Internet meme weirdo, so sue me.  Yes, they're the names of viral Internet memes.

Internet explosion in Cambodia

The number of Internet users is rising steadily, however the vast majority are mobile users, which means less coding, more consuming!

Whaddup Facebook?

  • 1,200,000 Cambodian Facebook users in 2013
  • 840,000 of which log in on a smartphone
  • Every two minutes a new Cambodian user joins Facebook!

Fun Facts!  

Cambodia was the first country in the world to have more mobile phones than landlines. Each person in Cambodia on average owns 1.3 active cell phones, which means cell phones outnumber people. In 2013, 1M smartphones were sold in Cambodia. That means one fifteenth of the entire population got a smartphone last year. A whopping 98 percent of Khmer Internet users get on the net through mobiles.

Where will KhodeUp be located?

Glad you asked!  FLOW orphanage is located just outside of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia.


Other Ways You Can Help

Feel free to contact us at khodeup@gmail.com with any suggestions.  If you'd like to get involved we'd be happy to try to incorporate you in any way!  

Please share this on your various social media and remember:

"Unity is strength...when there is teamwork and collaboration, wonderful things can be achieved."
Mattie Stepanek
story_txt:
What Is This Anyway?Does KhodeUp sound far-fetched? Let me change your mind.My half-brother and five cousins grew up in an orphanage outside Phnom Penh. The youngest two are still there. Except for Rith, who works on a farm, the older kids all work in the ‘hospitality’ industry where they feel lucky to earn $80/month.I’ve traveled to visit them five times, spending a total of 23 weeks in Cambodia. My brother and I have always loved hanging out at the orphanage. The kids are just like us -- funny, smart, and curious about the world. When I was there last November I talked to Srey Art, a girl who won the education lottery. She's coming to the US for college. I asked what she wants to study, then I practically punched the wall when I heard her answer. She really really wants to study computers, but she has no experience. So she'll study business instead. !@#$%*!#!!!To understand why that answer so offends me, you've got to know that I’m a tech addict. I started simple coding in kindergarten, moving on to website design when I was 11. Last summer I spent eight weeks at Twitter with Girls Who Code, and I’ll study computer science when I go to college next year. Until the immersion program at Twitter, I was completely self-taught. Like most coders, all I needed to get started was a computer and an Internet connection.
Within a couple hours of the conversation with Srey Art, I started
researching Internet/computer science opportunities in Phnom Penh. Two things stood out: the exponential growth of smart phones in
Cambodia, and the dearth of websites designed by and for Khmer users. The
conclusion: huge opportunity for Khmer web developers. Entering this
field has a low bar in terms of assets and infrastructure: a
laptop, a good Internet connection, and a basic introduction to coding. These
are all things that we can provide through KhodeUp.The idea gains real
urgency when you compare what my cousins make waiting on tables ($80/month) to
the going rate for building a website in Phnom Penh ($200/site).
Will all KhodeUp students become web developers? Probably not. But a few will, and the rest will get language practice and tech skills that will be huge assets in other fields. We've talked with a lot of people about this class, and I'm confident the model is solid. If KhodeUp is successful this summer we can recruit more instructors and scale it.This class is going to change lives. Who wouldn’t want to be a part of that? Help me get these teens started. I’ll keep in touch with you so you can see what they accomplish. They can’t wait. Neither can I.What We Need & What You GetThe 2014 pilot program is a four-week immersion class for 20-30 older
teens at Future Light Orphanage outside of Phnom Penh. Students will learn
HTML, CSS, and the basics of JavaScript and design.
Our $15,000 goal will cover equipment, software, an Internet upgrade, web hosting, airfare, and room and board. 
If  tax-deductible contributions outpace our expenses, we can provide  incentives for the kids to start their own tech businesses or to teach others, as well as a year-round part-time instructor to help continue the learning.We are affiliated with eGlobal Family and FLOW Orphanage. Through the emotional and financial support of eGlobal Family foster parents, sponsored children are afforded the opportunity to develop into more confident and self-reliant individuals. For 10 years the organization has supported hundreds of children at Future Light Orphanage in Cambodia and has recently formed new partnerships with orphanages throughout Southeast Asia. These are not religiously affiliated organizations.Ah!  Here's the fun stuff you can get with a tax-deductible contribution!  For just $25 you can get some snazzy stickers. I know I love stickers.  A mere $100 gets you a personal thank you note from a KhodeUp student.  For $250 you get a personal invite to participate in Demo Day at the end of the program, where you'll be able to watch our students present their final projects via Internet. (Pray to the Wifi Gods and don't worry, if you can't make it we will record the whole event and post it on our Vimeo later!) Those in the MoonMoon category at $1,000 can Skype with some of our students about their projects.Kramas, traditional Khmer scarves, are  a fun perk for the Ermagherd ($500) and MoonMoon ($1,000) donor levels. These uniquely Cambodian scarves can adorn your neck, wrap around your waist, keep out the sun, and hoist a live chicken.FAQ!What's up with the .kh? People ask this a lot. Kh is Cambodia's web-extension. More importantly, "kh" is my way of signifying Khmer, which means Cambodian. 
So that "kh" means this program belongs to Khmer teens. KhodeUp will give them the
skills, gear, and continuing troubleshooting they need to start building
websites for Khmer clients. What the heck is up with your donor level names?  Okay I'm an Internet meme weirdo, so sue me.  Yes, they're the names of viral Internet memes.Internet explosion in CambodiaThe number of Internet users is rising steadily, however the vast majority are mobile users, which means less coding, more consuming!Whaddup Facebook?
1,200,000 Cambodian Facebook users in 2013
840,000 of which log in on a smartphone
Every two minutes a new Cambodian user joins Facebook!
Fun Facts!  Cambodia was the first country in the world to have more mobile phones than landlines. Each person in Cambodia on average owns 1.3 active cell phones, which means cell phones outnumber people. In 2013, 1M smartphones were sold in Cambodia. That means one fifteenth of the entire population got a smartphone last year. A whopping 98 percent of Khmer Internet users get on the net through mobiles.Where will KhodeUp be located?Glad you asked!  FLOW orphanage is located just outside of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia.Other Ways You Can HelpFeel free to contact us at khodeup@gmail.com with any suggestions.  If you'd like to get involved we'd be happy to try to incorporate you in any way!  Please share this on your various social media and remember:"Unity is strength...when there is teamwork and collaboration, wonderful things can be achieved."Mattie Stepanek

story:
The Purpose:

We know that children are more than just test scores.  Roots & Wings Community School is a free public school that fights for every student's right to enjoy a childhood of boundless curiosity.  We don't teach them how to sit in line, we help them change the world - right here, right now.

Rite of Passage - our End-of-Year Tradition (May)

From a rustic camp setting at the Sangre de Cristo Youth Ranch to Wilderness, we create group adventures: rafting, service projects, farming, herding goats... followed by 24-hour solos, campfire songs and a lifetime of memories.

Chaco Canyon (April)

We teach through expeditions of the mind.  Our studies of ancient civilizations and sacred geometry will take us to Chaco Canyon.  We'll live as the ancients for 5 days - hiking to archaeological sites and deciphering a monumental code to the heavens.

Urban Adventure and Hiking in Bandolier (March) 

At the Museum of Indian Arts and Culture in Santa Fe with an anthropologist, we'll explore New Mexico prehistory.  In Albuquerque, we'll visit UNM archeology & cosmology departments, the Planetarium & the award-winning Fractal Friday show.  In Bandolier, we'll investigate the architecture of the Ancient Puebloans' cliff dwellings.

What You Get: 

The staff at RWCS volunteers to produce these world class experiences at an absolute minimum cost.  We give these trips to 34 students in the 4th – 8th grades for the SAME COST as 5 students on a typical commercial outdoor adventure. Our guides are highly certified and have a combined experience of 75 + yrs in the field.

REWARDS: As an expression of thanks, choose from our students' offerings of Virtual Expedition experience (online photos & artwork posted) Wilderness Haiku poems, architectural designs for Meditation Labyrinths & more  --->

The Impact:

These trips foster our students' emotional, physical and social growth and ignite a lifelong love of learning.  We grow whole people at our school!

GO BIG:

The final category has the largest contribution suggestion - but hey, feel free to write in any large number!  Your generosity goes straight into the minds of our students. Spread the word by posting this link on your social media or forward to anyone you know who supports real education in public schools. Cheers!

story:
Author Melissa Davis                      Pen Name: Stormie Dunn

Is a US Army Veteran, a graduate of Sam Houston State University with a degree in Criminal Justice and an advocate for fellow Military Sexual Trauma victims and their family.

PTSD is a disabling anxiety disorder battled on a daily basis. It is a battle we win on some days and lose on other days. It leaves the veteran with the constant feeling of danger and doom. It leaves us in a constant state of fear, stress, anxiety, and distrust even when we know we are safe. It leaves many of us in a depression so thick we try to mask it with drugs, alcohol, and other self-harming acts even to the point of suicide. Military Sexual Trauma has lasting effects on the veteran, their families, friends, employers, and the government.

Our families, friends and coworkers/employers live in this constant chaotic tornado called PTSD, because our fears, stress, anxiety and mistrust even applies to them. We trust no one! Not even ourselves! Our loved ones become our enemies and targets even when they have done nothing but support us.

The government suffers through lack of military readiness. How can our military be strong when its service members cannot even trust the soldier standing next to them or commanding them? It also suffers financially through the mental health issues that last a lifetime, disability payments, loss of work hours, and the list continues exponentially.

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking funding to film an educational aid as a training/awareness tool by the military for young recruits during their first week of in-processing. Inprocessing is the stage prior to going to your assigned boot camp training which is where a great portion of rapes occur and in the next level of training known as Military Occupational Training. 

We need $20,000 to pay for the production crew, travel to conduct interviews and promoting the training film once completed.

• Military Sexual Trauma should not be considered a career hazard as some legislators have said. It MUST be stopped! As a nation, we must demand it!

•If we do not reach our entire goal, the funds will be used to pay for the production crew, travel to conduct interviews and promoting until the documentary is completed. We WILL see this film produced!

How your contribution will make an impact:

• If 26,000 rapes a year were occurring in your neighborhood, society would DEMAND action. The military was/is our community and we are demanding a change. If the military was doing its job, there would not be crisis of the proportion currently reported and keep in mind, these numbers do not even begin to scrape at the unreported cases out of fear of retaliation or ending their military careers.

The men and women who dedicate their lives to serve our Country deserves to be afforded the same protection they insure for our citizens!!!

• I wrote my story and the story of two young soldiers who lost their lives to military sexual trauma. We must educate the young women and men who will enlist to protect our nation.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

•You can help by spreading the word about this campaign and and through sharing you are helping to ensure our soldiers are protected.

•Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

  • Call and write your local representatives and demand action on behalf of the soldiers!! Demand change at the company command level, imposes greater safety nets for the victims, and demand stronger punishments for offenders and those who retaliate/harass the victim after reporting.

story:
What is 2Gether International?

Founded in Mexico

2Gether International is a nonprofit which was founded over four years ago in Mexico by a young man named Diego Mariscal. Though he was born with Cerebral Palsy, Diego has never let his disability limit him, but Diego has experienced firsthand the difficulties that arise when a society is both inaccessible and unaccommodating. In short, 2Gether's goal is to emphasize the importance of disability as a part of human diversity.

2Gether chapters throughout Mexico have been hosting 2-3 day workshops for high school students for the past few years, simulating a variety of physical, sensory and cognitive disabilities. These simulations are followed by facilitated discussions which address the ways in which our communities inadvertently limit disabled persons. On the last day of the workshop, the high schoolers are joined by people with a variety of disabilities who are eager to break down the barriers between disabled and non-disabled persons. Together, everyone participates in activities such as wheelchair friendly Twister, balloon fights, slip & slide races and dance offs. The entire group then identifies the ways in which our communities could be more accessible and accommodating and the students develop plans of action. One project raised money to purchase wheelchairs for students who could not afford to do so (wheelchairs can be upward of $700 each!), while another group of students ran a campaign which put an end to improper elevator use.

Now Branching out to Washington, DC!

2Gether has officially earned nonprofit status in the U.S. and has established its first branch in Washington, DC at American University. My name is Tailor D'Ortona and as 2Gether's DC Branch Director, I will be coordinating 2Gether's first collegiate workshop this March! Last semester we hosted a workshop with 40 students from local DC high schools and after the event's success, we will be adjusting out model to create a dynamic 2 day workshop for students from George Washington, Georgetown, Catholic, Howard and Gallaudet University.

Ableism, along with the entire disability rights movement, is completely ignored throughout our education system, though disabled persons comprise America's LARGEST MINORITY! We want people to realize that disability is simply a natural part of human diversity and that disabilities, both visible and invisible, are not something which our societies should shame. Instead, 2Gether celebrates this aspect of human diversity and helps students to brainstorm how THEY can make our communities a more accessible and accommodating place for everyone. Now we need YOUR help to make our workshop a reality!

To Make Our Workshop a Reality...

We have been planning our Spring '14 DC Collegiate Workshop since our high school workshop proved so successful last October, but now we are in need of funds because government grants are not a sustainable way to run a successful, enduring nonprofit.

These are some of the things 2Gether needs help funding:

  • A speaker from the disability community- Last semester we hosted someone from the US International Council on Disabilities!
  • A professional interpreter for our speaker
  • Food for our participants (we often eat meals while blindfolded)
  • Participant and volunteer t-shirts
  • Supplies for our activities
  • Wheelchairs- we would REALLY like to invest in wheelchairs to be used at all of our future workshops!

Any excess funds which we do not use for our workshop are donated to 2Gether International in order to keep the nonprofit sustainable.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please help us to get the word out & make some noise about 2Gether's campaign by using the Indiegogo share tools!
  • "Like" us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/2getherInternational
  • Check out 2Gether's website: http://2gether-international.org/
  • Follow us on Twitter: @2gether_AU
  • Follow us on Instagram: 2gether-international


"We may have limitations, but 2Gether we have no limits!"

story: As you may know, Dustin Nash has recently accepted a visiting position at  Muhlenberg College in Allentown, PA for this coming academic year. Whether it has been as a husband, father, friend, or colleague, Dusty has always been there for the people close to him. As Dusty, Lorena, Elias, and Ruby get ready to move to Allentown for this next chapter in their lives, it would be great if we could all pitch in a little something to make sure it is a smooth transition.

story:
Mon nom est Yasmine Lavoine, j'ai 16 ans, et je fais partie du Ghana Humanitarian Project 2014 de l'école International de Paris. Ce projet à été créé par Madame Cyrille Lavallé. Le projet a tout d'abord débuté en Namibie, puis au Ghana. J'ai eu la chance de participer à cet echange culturel l'année dernière et de m'y engager pour 3 belles semaines. 3 semaines consacrées à plusieurs buts. Nous leurs avons donné des leçons de mathématiques, d'anglais et de sciences, fait des préventions sur le Sida, et la Malaria, nous avons pris en charge le jardin d'enfants du village, et avons construit une bibliothèque. Cette année, même programme, sauf que c'est un orphelinat que nous construisons! 

 L’Afrique est un pays qui m’a toujours intéressée, parce que je pense qu’il regorge de mystères et d’intérêts qu’on ne peut pas connaître si on ne les a pas vécus. Alors quand j’ai su que j’avais l’occasion de pouvoir résoudre ça, je n’ai pas hésité un seul instant et je me suis présentée. Vivre au Ghana pendant 3 semaines et avoir un échange avec les habitants de Tafi Atome a été l’expérience la plus enrichissante de ma vie, car elle m’a appris énormément. Sur l’Afrique et sur moi même. J’ai appris à connaître un peuple qui m’était inconnu, leur façon de vivre, de voir les choses d’un nouvel oeil et je me suis rendu compte que j’avais beaucoup de chance. Le Projet Humanitaire apporte autant aux habitants qu’aux élèves, parce qu’il nous permet de sortir de notre bulle. C’est une sorte de remerciement de leur part, en échange de l’aide que nous leur apportons. 

Le petit garçon sur la photo s'appelle Lucky. Il est l'une des raison pour laquelle je retourne au Ghana l'été prochain. Afin d'être près de lui.

Merci d'avance pour votre générosité et votre aide

Yasmine

story:
Do you believe PEACE is possible?

CISV educates and inspires action for a more just and peaceful world. CISV is a global community of dedicated volunteers, creating opportunities for all ages to experience the excitement and enrichment of cultural diversity through our educational programs. We are founded on our belief that peace is possible through friendship - and that the real difference can be made by starting with children. 

Following the devastation of World War II, there was a need for initiatives that could help to build and maintain peace. Dr. Doris Allen, a child pychologist, believed that the ultimate source for peace, long range, lay with the children. From this conviction came her vision of bringing together children from all over the globe to learn to respect different and common values. In 1951, she realized her dream when delegates from eight countries gathered in Cincinnati, USA for the first Children's International Summer Village (CISV). Since 1951, more than 190,000 people from 70 countries have participated in more than 5000 international peace programs through CISV.

CISV has a vision of a more just and peaceful world; we believe that we can all take responsibility for making this happen.

Help us begin to achieve it.

This fundraising campaign was created to help raise funds for our newly selected 2014 delegates from the CISV Chapter in Michigan City, Indiana.

There are 34 individuals from the Michigan City area that have been selected to attend CISV programs in 8 different countries this summer. Most of these individuals are children that have been chosen to attend Village (11 year olds) or Step Up (14-15 year olds) programs. In these programs, the kids will be living for a month in an international camp setting where 9-12 different countries are represented by delegations of 4 youth and an adult leader. Our Michigan City delegations will represent the USA in their respective camps while learning about diversity, human rights, sustainable development, and conflict resolution. With their newly made friends from around the world, they will learn to respect other cultures, appreciate similarities, and embrace differences.

Many of our families are struggling to gather the funds needed to attend the programs that they have been chosen for (flights to the Faroe Islands and Turkey aren't cheap!) Of course we don't want any child to have to turn down the opportunity of a lifetime because of financial concerns. Let's help to give all of these children the ability to grow as individuals, learn about other corners of the world, and breakdown stereotypes.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $5000 to put towards scholarships for those Michigan CIty delegates that need it most. All of the raised funds, regardless of whether or not we reach our entire goal, will be divided among those that apply for financial help through our CISV chapter. 

CISV is a charitable, independent, non-political, volunteer organization promoting peace education and cross-cultural friendship. CISV Michigan City is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization so your donations are tax deductible.

If you contribute, you can receive some pretty great perks too! Who wouldn't want to get a postcard from another country?! Plus, you will know that in some small way, you have started the idea in a child's mind that peace is possible. And I think that's a great idea to nurture in all children.

The Impact

Taking part in a CISV educational program is an experience that can have a powerful and transformative effect on these individuals for their entire life. The positive impact of meeting and making friends with children from other countries and cultures cannot be overestimated. These individuals will gain a global perspective and come to understand their part in our global community.

Here is another fantastic video about CISV, the philosophy behind it, and the amazing programs that are hosted all over the world. This video was made by CISV Ecuador.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4rYXXQ1yD4k

While CISV puts an emphasis on fun and friendship, at the core of everything we do is our aim to educate and inspire young people to realize their full potential. The curriculum in each of our programs is age-appropriate and delivered using our informal, 'learning by doing' approach. The CISV programs help individuals develop an 'anything is possible' attitude, leadership and communication skills, and an understanding of the world around them.

This project is valuable to the delegates, our CISV Michigan City chapter, and to the world. These individuals will come home believing peace is possible, and will hopefully continue to work towards peace locally as well as internationally.

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you can’t financially contribute at this time, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help us out in other important ways:

  • Help get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! Share this page with your family and friends!
  • Attend a CISV Michigan City monthly chapter meeting to see what we're all about and to get involved! We love to see new faces in our community. Email michigancitycisv@gmail.com for more information.

Do you believe PEACE is possible? CISV educates and inspires action for a more just and peaceful world. CISV is a global community of dedicated volunteers, 
creating opportunities for all ages to experience the excitement and 
enrichment of cultural diversity through our educational programs. We 
are founded on our belief that peace is possible through friendship - 
and that the real difference can be made by starting with 
children. 
Following the devastation of World War II, there was a need for initiatives that could help to build and
    maintain peace. Dr. Doris Allen, a child pychologist, believed
    that the ultimate source for peace, long range, lay with the children. From this conviction came her vision of bringing together children from all over the globe to
    learn to respect different and common values. In 1951, she realized her dream when delegates from
    eight countries gathered in Cincinnati, USA for the first Children's International Summer Village
    (CISV). Since 1951, more than 190,000 people from 70 countries have
    participated in more than 5000 international peace programs through CISV. CISV has a vision of a more just and peaceful world; we believe that we 
can all take responsibility for making this happen. Help us begin to achieve it. 
This fundraising campaign was created to help raise funds for our newly selected 2014 delegates from the CISV Chapter in Michigan City, Indiana. story:
Good news everyone!

We have been very fortunate with goods and labour donated that we have been able to reduce our required finances down to $20 000. 
Over the last month we have completed a great deal of work during our days off, and we have had a number of local tradies and business operators give their time to help complete technical and difficult work. 
We are very happy to announce that our epoxy floor is complete and already in use through normal trade! 
We've also removed the dangerous wooden platform (ready for it to be recycled into benches) and we've completed the essential plastering on the ceiling and walls.
We still have a long way to go, but we are happy with our progress and we're exciting for the coming weeks!

What we are and what we're doing

We are not your average local cafe, we are your local safe place, your chat room and your food bowl. We make excellent coffee and tasty food, and we want to take care of our community. On top of that, I am a qualified trainer and assessor with a strong background in hospitality. 

We operate 7 days a week, serving breakfast, lunch, coffee and cocktails and we provide a delivery service for both lunch (7 days a week) and breakfast (weekends only). 

We take part in the suspended coffee program, and we provide accounts for people who need a feed but can't pay today. 

We see our community struggling through tough times and we look for ways to make people happier, even if its just by turning up the cheerful music we play. 

We enjoy our work, and want the community to enjoy our space and to have a place to go to finish school assignments, learn the art of coffee, or learn how to cook poached eggs. We proofread assignments, give advice on analysing poetry and help write job applications. 

We want to turn our cafe into a training centre to teach people in need valuable and long lasting job skills that can be used anywhere in the world. 


What We Need & What You Get

We need a total of $50000

- Approximately $5000 for flooring and coving on the wall 

- Approximately $7000 for a new oven

- Approximately $12000 for a new industrial cool room

- $6500 for a purpose built bar with taps

- $15000 to completely support and plaster the ceiling in the proposed training area

If we don't reach our entire goal, we will focus on the floor as a priority. We plan for the floor to be completely non-slip and anti-fatigue to prevent injuries. Our second priority is the industrial cool-room to store the additional supplies we'll need for training. 

If we come in under budget, all left over funds will be either donated to local food programs or put towards a similar funding project. We'll contact contributors if this happens for your input. 

The Bang For Your Buck

We have special perks for contributors! From your photo on our Wall of Heroes to mugs, t-shirts and lifetime discounts and advertising space on our coffee cups.


    The Impact

    Our community demographics are predominantly low socio-economic in make up, and much of the reason for this is the lack of employment opportunities in the area. At the moment, I have 10 employees on my roster, and not enough hours to give all of them. I receive between 5 and 15 employment enquiries every week, and most of these are new enquiries. Many of the new enquiries are from young people who either don't have experience in a work environment, or have limited experience and limited skills in a very small number of tasks. If we could provide targeted training to even 10% of these young people, I believe we could begin to rejuvenate the entire community with hope and new prospects. 

    Hope is contagious, and if we can give a young person hope for a bright future, we're doing the whole world a favour. 

    Our cafe is already a safe place for people to hangout and be themselves: we provide free wifi, and a good mix of music for people to enjoy and we are building a toy library for the small ones to enjoy. Providing targeted training is just the next step in building our business and entrenching ourselves as part of the community. 

    We already accept students from the local schools on work placement and work experience programs, and we see ourselves partnering with colleges and training centres to extend students learning into a more work based environment. 

      Risks & Challenges

      The biggest risk we face is losing our customer base, so we are always reaching out to the community to grow and retain this customer base. We are doing this through visible advertising, rejuvenating the shop's appearance and providing a live music venue to the local performers. 

      We plan to continuously consult with other local (and successful) business owners, financial planners and accountants to ensure we stay on track. Let's face it: hospitality is a big risk and there's a lot of work that needs to be done to make a business successful and keep it that way.

      We have a comprehensive business plan that is reviewed at the end of every quarter to make sure we're on track for our core goals. 

      We love our loyal customers and we have a strong repeat customer base that is growing every week. We are always marketing to new and potential customers while also taking care of our existing customers with loyalty programs and special deals.  

      We believe that the more successful we are, the more successful the whole area will be, and we want this to be happy and prosperous community. 

        Spread the word!

        Noise is just as valuable as cash, so please share with your friends, and shout hope to the world!

We have a comprehensive business plan that is reviewed at the end of every quarter to make sure we're on track for our core goals. 
We love our loyal customers and we have a strong repeat customer base that is growing every week. We are always marketing to new and potential customers while also taking care of our existing customers with loyalty programs and special deals.

story:
THOU SHALL NOT LEARN will be a bold, eye-catching and provocative public service announcement.  We all remember “This is Your Brain on Drugs.” Isn’t it time we asked what your brain would be like without education?  Funny, unrestrained and certainly unforgettable, this 30-second spot will demonstrate that when it comes to sex ed, less isn’t more. 

 

Right now, America is at the tipping point.  The 2012 election campaign has been an echo chamber of untruths.  Never before has the need for objective, scientific, non-partisan education been more necessary.

 

We’re a group of filmmakers, activists and educators who feel like we can no longer sit by and do nothing.  Pooling our resources, we’ve already begun with an op-ed in The Huffington Post and an educational event at the University of Southern California with Planned Parenthood which is going to take place on January 23, 2012.  The next step is to get the word out even further.  An entertaining, punchy PSA is a great way to get people talking on Facebook and Twitter, on the blogs and most importantly (although we tend to forget this) to each other about this fundamental issue – education.

 

Where is the money going?  We’re calling in a lot of favors and getting as much as we can for free.  Your money is only going to what we absolutely have to pay for - from insurance and equipment to locations and feeding the crew and cast. 

 

THE TEAM


Jamie Ruddy – Writer / Director

 

Jamie graduated from NYU’s film school where she directed two award-winning shorts and penned a third award-winner. She also won the outstanding achievement in screenwriting for the entire film program and landed a job writing a period feature for Universal Studios. Since then she has started to direct commercials for hire, shot a third award-winning short and is slated to helm her first feature film in Hong Kong, a European/Asian crime thriller in English, Cantonese and Mandarin.

 

Simon Radford - Producer

 

Simon is a Provost's Fellow at the University of Southern California. He was a candidate for the UK parliament in 2005, increasing his party's vote share by almost 33%. He has trained democracy groups from Egypt, Turkey, Belarus and Ukraine in campaigning and messaging strategy. He has been published in Commonweal, The Liberal, and The Providence Journal. Previously Simon worked for Deloitte Consulting in London for clients in a variety of sectors, from banking strategy to political communications for regional government. He is a graduate of Peterhouse, Cambridge University and received his Masters at Brown.

 

Lenora Claire – Producer / Casting Director

 

Described by the LA Weekly as a “real life Jessica Rabbit” and named one of their 2011 “People of the Year”, Lenora is a Los Angeles based multiple career juggling glamour gal who takes all of her absurd projects very seriously. After appearing on TMZ, NPR, NBC, LA Times, National Enquirer, LA Bizarro and various other media, Lenora is perhaps best known as a national news-making curator following the success of her Golden Gals Gone Wild art show, featuring erotic depictions of the Golden Girls.  Lenora has also worked on developing TV projects with Doron Ofir, the #1 reality TV casting agent in the world (Jersey Shore, Millionaire Matchmaker, Rupal’s Drag Race).

 

Andrew Klayman – Producer

 

Andrew is co-founder of Love Honor Cherish, a non-profit organization dedicated to repealing Prop. 8 in California.  As a writer and filmmaker, Andrew produced various media campaigns in his work with Love Honor Cherish.  He is a UCLA graduate with a background in finance (Disney, Fox and TV Guide).  Andrew now serves as the chief global strategist for an Indian-based company.

 

Rupert Russell - Producer

 

Rupert graduated top of his class at Cambridge University, Jesus College, and is currently a PhD candidate at Harvard University.  A frequent contributor to The Huffington Post, he writes on a variety of social and political issues, and is currently writing his first book.

story:
Short Summary

BlueStamp Engineering is an intensive six-week summer program for high school students to design technologies they find personally interesting. At BlueStamp, we give the students control of their projects and what they do. Students select a project from over 120 choices, or find one on their own that they are personally passionate about.  The focus of their time with the program is getting their project to work and posting full documentation online. They will be cutting, drilling, coding, soldering, and best of all, troubleshooting (all depending on the project of course). Our instructors and TAs are all engineering students at world-renowned universities, such as Stanford, Berkeley, Columbia, Cornell, NYU, Rice, etc. We maintain a ~3:1 student to teacher ratio so that students can get real help from the staff despite each student having their own individual project.

We need your help

Our unique, individually based curriculum, where we give the students the freedom to choose their projects, makes BlueStamp more expensive to run. We choose our students based on their motivation and interest. Yet, unfortunately, some of them cannot pay their entire tuition for the summer ($3,000 - $3500). The tuition covers space, instructors, and all project materials which the student keeps to further work on and impress colleges and companies. We need your help to ensure that they will be able to attend, learn, and grow regardless of financial situations.

We are launching this campaign with $10,000 on Indiegogo. Hopefully, with your help, we can surpass our goals and help more students!  Even if we do not reach our goal, we will use the money we receive to help these students reach their full potential.

The Impact

This will be BlueStamp’s third summer, the last two having gone extremely well. Our first year was just 10 students based in New York. Last summer, we had 21 in New York and 8 in Houston. This summer we hope to have 40 in New York, 20 in Houston, and 20 in San Francisco. As you can see, we are expanding faster and faster to help more students gain the skills they will need to succeed.

Please browse our “Meet the Students” page on our website to see first hand the students who benefit from our program and their projects. Our students leave with knowledge and skills that would have been difficult to get on their own.  Recently, several of our students were featured on Liberty TreeHouse, a cable tv show where they dsicussed their work.  In addition, just a few months ago we gave a TED talk where we discussed our motivation behind starting BlueStamp. 

Your help will make all the difference to these students. They have worked hard to get to where they are, but only with your help, can they continue to rise against the barriers that face them.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t contribute, there are other ways you can help us out:

Please try to get the word out about BlueStamp through social media or through parents and teachers you may know. We want to involve as many motivated students as possible!

If you know of any education or STEM investors, please tell us. We are always trying to find new ways to help our students.

story:
PRESENTATION (WHO ARE WE)

We are a small group of students from Kranj (Slovenia). We are discovering and presenting Slovenian cultural heritage.

We have already successfully finished a few projects, where we demonstrated our skills and know-how in presenting field work to those, who are interested. Our goal is to present our work in archaeology and national heritage to common people.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_emb...

As it is visible from the link above, we are currently working on castles. We work as an unit, which means that all decisions are made together! We do this also for the revival of the past from the visual field remains to be presented to the public of the past archaeological sites. At the same time all our projects provide us with additional experience in archeology, history, architecture and multimedia world.

OUR CURRENT PROJECT

On February 23rd 2013 we will launch the presentation of our documentary film about the Castle Waldenberg (Pusti grad, Radovljica, Slovenia). Presentation of the documentary film will be launched on 24th of February on this page and Youtube.

OUR VISION

We would love to continue with our work, but face an obstacle – our leader, Rok Bremec, is moving to Canada by the end of March 2013, and is taking all the equipment that we used in our work, with him. That leaves us without any equipment. We want people to get to know their national history, from pre-historic era to the Second World War. Our goal is to present Slovenian herritage as effective as possible.

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

Our current problem lies in terms of lack of financial support in Slovenia. For continuation of the project we would  need 5000 EUR. The money would be used for purchasing a camera, a videocamera and a computer. This would cost us about 2500 EUR. For the documentary (02/23/2013), we need a producer who would help us make a high quality film. That will be Uroš Šterbenk and it would cost around 500 EUR for all the video and audio work. For the 3D reconstruction of the castle Waldenberg we would hire Gregor Novaković (MAGELAN Skupina, d.o.o.), which costs 2000 EUR, but that would also include quality tutoring in working with AutoCAD, 3ds MAX and Cinema4D. The 2000 EUR also include the use of Leica Scanstation C10. This would be signifficant in our future work.

WE OFFER:

Each donator will be mentioned in the credits of the documentary.

Other ways you can help

If you have a project that would benefit you (reconstruction, scanning and making scale models of any objects), we are also at your disposal.

In case of exceeding our goals, we would start our next project, the Gutenberg Castle in Tržič.

SPONSORS

We would like to thank all of our sponsors, present (Magelan skupina, d.o.o., Zlate ostroge) and future. Sincere thanks!
story_txt:
PRESENTATION (WHO ARE WE)
We are a small group of students from Kranj (Slovenia). We are discovering and presenting Slovenian cultural heritage.
We have already successfully finished a few projects, where we demonstrated our skills and know-how in presenting field work to those, who are interested. Our goal is to present our work in archaeology and national heritage to common people.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_emb...
As it is visible from the link above, we are currently working on castles. We work as an unit, which means that all decisions are made together! We do this also for the revival of the past from the visual field remains to be presented to the public of the past archaeological sites. At the same time all our projects provide us with additional experience in archeology, history, architecture and multimedia world.
OUR CURRENT PROJECT
On February 23rd 2013 we will launch the presentation of our documentary film about the Castle Waldenberg (Pusti grad, Radovljica, Slovenia). Presentation of the documentary film will be launched on 24th of February on this page and Youtube.
OUR VISION
We would love to continue with our work, but face an obstacle – our leader, Rok Bremec, is moving to Canada by the end of March 2013, and is taking all the equipment that we used in our work, with him. That leaves us without any equipment. We want people to get to know their national history, from pre-historic era to the Second World War. Our goal is to present Slovenian herritage as effective as possible.
WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET
Our current problem lies in terms of lack of financial support in Slovenia. For continuation of the project we would  need 5000 EUR. The money would be used for purchasing a camera, a videocamera and a computer. This would cost us about 2500 EUR. For the documentary (02/23/2013), we need a producer who would help us make a high quality film. That will be Uroš Šterbenk and it would cost around 500 EUR for all the video and audio work. For the 3D reconstruction of the castle Waldenberg we would hire Gregor Novaković (MAGELAN Skupina, d.o.o.), which costs 2000 EUR, but that would also include quality tutoring in working with AutoCAD, 3ds MAX and Cinema4D. The 2000 EUR also include the use of Leica Scanstation C10. This would be signifficant in our future work.

Each donator will be mentioned in the credits of the documentary.

If you have a project that would benefit you (reconstruction, scanning and making scale models of any objects), we are also at your disposal.
In case of exceeding our goals, we would start our next project, the Gutenberg Castle in Tržič.
SPONSORS
We would like to thank all of our sponsors, present (Magelan skupina, d.o.o., Zlate ostroge) and future. Sincere thanks!
